column8:
There are times when I can enjoy this game. Most of the time I just tolerate it. For your sake (you, go drink some water), I wouldn't recommend this game. It's a glitch-fest and written badly. In arenas, every car will target you (counterpoint: the chaos can be enjoyable), in races cars handle like boats (counterpoint: learning how to circumvent the issues is satisfying) and the game overall feels hollow (counterpoint: ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø).

It feels like a product of its time and yet much older (NFS High Stakes felt more progressively rewarding). Character models look like something out of a mobile game (worse than Payback 2 on Android, actually). The cars aren't memorable. The zombie hunting mode is alright, but damage against and from other cars is more inconsistemt than many DS games (they're like 32MB tops for goodness sake, look into it one way or another).

The soundtrack is pretty cool though.

TL;DR, don't spend more than a quid on this if you must.
‚Äì‚Äì‚Äì
Technical stuff (skip to the like button if you don't care):
In 2025 I played on Linux Mint 22.1 (now 22.2) with an AMD 4500U. I get 60fps everywhere with Proton 9 (save for very heavy explosions), but restarts freeze the game for 3 seconds. I think it did this when I originally played on Windows 10 with an AMD A9-9400 APU (HP 24-e080na), so don't expect the game to be solid.

The physics are a bit odd ‚Äì the cars sometimes behave like cardboard.
The graphics are outdated even for the time of release.
They lack the warmth of the first games ‚Äì it feels like they were made by a different studio.
6/10 ‚Äì It's worth a try for fun, but don't expect a masterpiece. Suitable for those who just want to control the game without deep immersion.

Guys, what can I say about this game? I bought it at a racing festival. If you want to play it, I recommend buying the Flatout Complete Pack. Okay, let's move on to the review. What I'm focusing on is the physics, but understand, guys.
If you ignore the physics, the game is really cool. There are lots of cars, characters, game modes, and a lot of maps.
There are achievements, you can choose characters to suit your taste, but for some reason, players leave negative reviews. There's a lot of content there.
I recommend this game right away.

The game is the best in the series, from the end.
It's a top-notch game if you don't play it.
The "Psychological Horror" label is justified.

column9:
God Flatout 3... I don't know what was going through my head when I decided to play this title and on top of that, platinum it üíÄ They already label it as psychological horror XDD

Well, as we know, it's one of the worst games reviewed on the platform, what can I say... it's bad, yes, hahaha, but I didn't find any bugs that affect or damage your game. At most, you'd go down an elevated ramp and your car would fly through the air, very randomly, but that didn't happen much. Otherwise, it has a wide variety of customizable vehicles, which are unlocked as you win events. If you're skilled at driving, you'll manage to master the driving and style of the game... (if you can handle it).

There are a lot of events. The monster truck and killing zombies seemed quite fun to me. The rest, well... sometimes you run into a really broken AI that you'll never be able to catch. Luckily, you can leave the race and re-enter so that another rival can appear. Regarding achievements, it takes a while in the races, which are several, and just in case... If that weren't enough, they give you a challenge mode so you can replay most of the tests you managed to overcome lol

Don't play it for your own good ‚ò†Ô∏è but, if you're an achievement hunter and want a challenge, go ahead and suffer like me. Keep in mind that you need a friend to get the achievement for playing an online match; the rest is single-player.
Goodbye Flatout 3, I'm proud to have you next to my completed games üç∑

column9: I do not recommend it, it is not worth your time or your computer.
The game isn't all that bad (Undercover alone is worth mentioning). Sure, there are a few bugs and the physics aren't great, but it could have been worse...
...I'm in shock

Despite the game's "Extremely Negative" ratings, I decided to check it out myself, as most reviews don't provide any specifics.

So, why is the game so bad?

The menu regularly greets us with a pop-up information window, strongly recommending we get a performance rating (this was the same metric in Windows 7; perhaps they're referring to something else, but I'm not sure). In addition to the main menu, this request to enter a rating also appears in the graphics settings. Moreover, you can't access the advanced settings without entering a rating. Fortunately, this window only appears on the first launch, although I still couldn't access the advanced settings afterward. The game is generally poorly optimized, with noticeable lags every time I navigate through the menu items.

The controls are very unresponsive‚Äîthe car slides along the road like a box of naswar in the developer's pocket, but at the same time, it feels glued to the track surface and is very reluctant to respond to your steering attempts. At the same time, as soon as a collision occurs, the car will launch into near-Earth orbit, spinning around its axis, but the chance of this happening is only 50/50 with each collision with a foreign object.

Graphics. I'm not one to criticize a game for poor graphics, because it can always be played up with style and give the game a certain retro charm. Even without that, I almost never have complaints about a game with a clear lack of anti-aliasing or poorly executed effects. However... When I set the settings to "ultra" and see some kind of "jaggy" blur, I have questions, because a 2011 game looks like a console/mobile port of an obscure low-budget game.

There's no career mode, as far as I know. Instead, we'll be treated to a series of challenges (50 in total) and other game modes, each of which can apparently be customized by selecting the number of opponents, laps, and other attributes. There's no tuning; sometimes you can only select ready-made presets for specific tasks. Although the car's parameters are specified, you're not shown how they change depending on the tuning selected...

What modes are there in the game?

A regular race
- Derby (for some reason, divided into two types: large and small)
- "Find and destroy something on a big truck"
- Bolt racing
- Night racing in rain and fog
- Off-roading with no rules, but with scoring for certain actions
- Driving along a route with zombies that you have to knock down to earn points
- Stunts where you can't even control the driver's "launch" (in previous games, the game showed the "throw" angle and slowed down time for accuracy, but this is not the case here)

The game doesn't remember camera settings between races, although this was the case in the previous two games. It's a small thing, but annoying.

The game also calculates stats rather strangely, which might have something to do with the metric system, but I'm not sure. For example, your 2-meter jump might be displayed as a 20-meter jump. This probably doesn't matter, but it struck me as odd, so I decided to point it out.

Verdict: Not worth your attention (and certainly not your money).

I've completed the game... don't ask me why.
It's hard for me to describe how it plays, but to me, it's very similar to playing with cars in kindergarten. There's no thrill. It doesn't feel like a racing game.

Cars explode and burst from any oncoming wind. Then they instantly respawn behind the leader (you, because there's no competition here at all), regardless of their previous location, even if they were two minutes behind.

The tracks are either very long and straight, or short and full of 90-degree turns.

There's no AI here. There are predetermined trajectories for the cars to follow. You can hit any car, and it will stare at the wall. For example, there are a couple of 1v1 races where the opponent starts off fast, then abruptly takes a 90-degree turn, literally flipping onto its side without losing speed, and then continues on. If you don't hit him while he's turning and knock him off course, you'll never have a chance to win. But if you do, he'll never be able to catch up.

The stunts in this series are a constant pain. Many rely solely on luck, like flying inside a sphere and trying to blow up a few barrels, but if any explosion sends you flying slightly off-course, you'll fail the challenge.

In short, this game is fun in places, but 95% of the time it's a completely boring, random experience. It's not a racing game, even though it looks like one.
10 out of 10, I recommend everyone to play!
Absolutely everything in this game and the game itself as a whole is an incredibly creepy, dull piece of crap!!!

column8: Terrible game. One of the worst I've played.
column9: Terrible game. One of the worst I've played.

What a disgrace. What this joke has to do with the Flatout series is beyond me. It's some kind of mobile port, with absolutely no physics or graphics.

I'd like to comment specifically on the physics. It feels like you're driving on rails; the grip is as unrealistic as possible.

Instead of a career mode, there are some mini-races, mini-games, a zombie mode (?!)

Level 19 is a clear indicator of the development team's incompetence. The game introduces a new feature: a tourist bus race (those famous red double-deckers from London). It would be great, except for the map with a chasm and ramps. The bus's speed is limited, and it's physically impossible to jump over the ramps. The bot keeps trying to do this, and the player has three options:

1. Turn off, delete, and forget about this piece of developer excrement.
2. Turn around and drive a circle backwards, reaching the checkpoint, and reset.
3. Edit the game file with the bus attributes, increasing its maximum speed.

I went with the second option, but only out of a desire to see all 40 levels, but I advise any sane person to either use the first option or, even better, not even install this disgrace.

At least, I managed to complete all 40 levels. I was glad to close this terrible chapter of my gaming journey and never return. It's a shame that the rights to this great series were acquired by some incompetent, greedy idiots.

The game has one of the worst ratings on Steam, which is good news. It means today's gamers still have a sense of taste.

column8:
Let's be real, everyone knows Flatout 3 sucks. But it is possible to enjoy it at times.

The car designs are unlikely to win fans among the fully-sighted, and for the most part their handling is intolerable, but there are maybe one or two per class that drive ok and are usable. The physics are... strange, but you get used to them after a bit. Events are very highly configurable, you can choose everything from the number of laps to the number of opponents and even what car classes the opponents are allowed to drive- but despite this events still tend to be very short and difficulty is all over the shop from race to race.

The one event that does last a good amount of time is the derby events, which I would argue are the best part of the whole game despite the very simplistic AI which simply makes a beeline for the player (like the cops in Driver on the PS1) and the slightly glitchy score system that encourages you to rub up against opponents more than ram them at speed. It's pretty fun and each derby might last about 5 minutes until your car blows up, but there aren't very many of them.

The Speed and Splatout events are decent too, Speed basically being normal races with proper racetracks and formula-style cars; and Splatout being a zombies mode where you drive around the regular circuits trying to run over as many people as possible, and as these use Race, Speed and Derby maps there are a lot of them to work through.

The maps range from pretty decent in design, maybe a 6/10, to redefining the word pain (looking at you, Tatras Mountains), but you can't deny there's plenty of variety throughout your playthrough. I'm not sure I'd have paid full price for this, but get it on sale and there's a good 3 or 4 hours of fun to be had.

Let's be real, everyone knows Flatout 3 sucks. But it is possible to enjoy it at times.

The car designs are unlikely to win fans among the fully-sighted, and for the most part their handling is intolerable, but there are maybe one or two per class that drive ok and are usable. The physics are... strange, but you get used to them after a bit. Events are very highly configurable, you can choose everything from the number of laps to the number of opponents and even what car classes the opponents are allowed to drive- but despite this events still tend to be very short and difficulty is all over the shop from race to race.

The one event that does last a good amount of time is the derby events, which I would argue are the best part of the whole game despite the very simplistic AI which simply makes a beeline for the player (like the cops in Driver on the PS1) and the slightly glitchy score system that encourages you to rub up against opponents more than ram them at speed. It's pretty fun and each derby might last about 5 minutes until your car blows up, but there aren't very many of them.

The Speed and Splatout events are decent too, Speed basically being normal races with proper racetracks and formula-style cars; and Splatout being a zombies mode where you drive around the regular circuits trying to run over as many people as possible, and as these use Race, Speed and Derby maps there are a lot of them to work through.

The maps range from pretty decent in design, maybe a 6/10, to redefining the word pain (looking at you, Tatras Mountains), but you can't deny there's plenty of variety throughout your playthrough. I'm not sure I'd have paid full price for this, but get it on sale and there's a good 3 or 4 hours of fun to be had.
The physics are bad; after parts 1 and 2, it feels like you're driving a toy car.

column8:
FlatOut 3, heh? It should be called ShatOut 3 because this game is a complete travesty. The physics are as broken as a shattered vase, the soundtrack is either not there at all or entirely sucks, the steering is so unstable that it hurts to drive, and by the end of it, you'll be laughing so hard at how bad it is that your voice with turn into nothing but empty air.

Not even the settings are done right. When my controller is set to keyboard, it instead recognizes my Xbox One controller. But when it's set to Xbox One controller settings, my controller doesn't work at all.

Seriously, this game does absolutely nothing right, and I'm shocked at how this game managed to follow up the fantastic FlatOut 2 at all.

column9: It's downright fashionable to hate this game. It's plenty fun, there's progression, Russian is the primary language, and you can become a tank driver (Ferocious Harry fires grenades when he hears the horn). You don't need any Forza-Huerza when you've got this meat.
Hidden gem, misunderstood masterpiece, snoops will continue to praise Kojima/Miyazaki while real divers play this.

column8:
tl;dr Get it on sale for less than a dollar if you want to experience the definition of mediocrity.

In my quest to get all achievements in my library this was next on my list. Finished in roughly 11 hours, and for a good hour or so was looking up how to beat some of the stuntman tracks. Apparently there is a control mechanic that is never explained or shown on screen for less than a milisecond. Turns out you can hit the eject key and get a jump mid air, imagine that.  This kind of constant trying to figure out stuff as I progressed was so annoying. I can tell that no testing went into seeing if everything can be completed. Example, there is a challenge where you have to drive a bus through the race track. Except the bus is so slow that a required jump in the track is impassable. So instead of driving the track like normal, you back track through the level to hit the required checkpoint, then drive back to the jump the other way around. The race is 3 laps so this took forever.

So as far as the gameplay goes. Its about what I expected from Flatout, except that quantity over quality doesn't work with the Flatout formula. The physics in this game are shit, that doesn't work well when the game is known for good crash physics.

I can plainly see this is a rushed shovelware game that left when it was deep in a beta state. Because who the crap decided that the tracks should be repeated about 5 times for "different event types". This got so repetitive and boring. Definition of milking what you have. 

Onto some more random notes I have. IF you intend on actually playing this game. DO THE CHALLENGES FIRST. 50 challenges that give you a preselected car and track setup. This helps alot when unlocking stuff because its a required mode to get all the achivements, and it gets you familiar with the tracks. The only good thing I can say is there are some funky options that allow you to make the game way faster to beat.

Use the Alarma Special car. Its the best car for handling. 

Some challenges and tracks require the speed to be set faster or classic rather than Default. This alludes to some of the options that can be set before you enter a race. There is a setting that can set how fast the gameplay/cars are. Yeah some fiddling was required in order to make it through some of the events.

Another bug, sometimes the AI can glitch and do an entire race with boost making it unwinnable, usually you can fix it by restarting the race. The AI will boost for a little when the race starts but I had about 40 times where the AIs boost never ran out so they just flew by never to be seen again.

The physics suck but some computers may benefit from disabling the multithreaded physics option in the menu. Apparently my computer is so beefy that the physics can break from how fast the physics calculations are handled. There is a setting in the options at the bottom to force the physics to run on a single core/thread only. 

Overall 3/10 Almost felt like playing Solitare, something so boring and mindless it sucks everything away until you realize you paid money to play this. Unless you happened to get this game with the Flatout bundle, which I hope is the only way this game makes it into peoples library.

column8: Esta cosa es tan exageradamente mala que en algun punto hasta llega a ser divertido por las risas. No hay nada salvable de este juego, es como si hubieran puesto todos sus esfuerzos en hacerlo lo mas lamentable posible. column9: This thing is so outrageously bad that at some point it's even funny for laughs. Playing this could be considered one of the top three most brutal torture games in history. CrapOut 3 is very good.
The most pathetic game I have ever played.

column9: The only thing I'm feeling pulsing through my veins while playing this game is just disappointment

The game was developed for fun. I was completely blown away by the physics, like the track was covered in lard and you'd fly off it like crazy when you slammed the handbrake. No, like the developers must have lived on the moon and designed it for lunar physics. Because there's simply no such physics on planet Earth. HOW the hell can a car go up to 100 km/h with just a slight push forward? And if you hit someone, the guy's fucked, not because you damaged him, but because the environment and his flight hundreds of meters away simply disintegrated him.

Hard fact
13th-century graphics, no bullshit.

Compared to the first and second, this game is only connected by the name and that's it. Well, it was cool that they made a bunch of characters with a story, but the game didn't get any better, it's like the Pascal engine was invented, it's better not to release the game than to make it so tasty and thin, like water being poured in, thank fucking GOD, I bought it for 10 pesos, fuck.

column8:
FlatOut 3‚Ä¶ un titre qui fait ressentir √† des millions d‚Äôindividus sur Terre, ainsi que dans les contr√©es lointaines d‚ÄôAndrom√®de et au-del√†, une sensation de d√©solation, d‚Äôapocalypse !

Le comble de l‚Äôironie, c‚Äôest qu‚Äôil n‚Äôa gu√®re de terres d√©sol√©es, et encore moins dans la capitale am√©ricaine, l√† o√π l‚Äôanalogie √† la troisi√®me retomb√©e radioactive guette l‚Äô≈ìil des plus perspicaces ‚Äî ou des psychotiques non loin des poubelles du Franprix de Sarcelles.

Je suis Fabrice Poisson-Om√©ga, et du haut de mes 38 ans, je croque la vie √† pleines dents ! Je fais des √©tudes sociologiques sur moult exp√©riences vid√©oludiques pour l‚Äô√©patement personnel de moi-m√™me. Et vous savez quoi ? C‚Äôest unanime !

Alors, ayez de gr√¢ce‚Ä¶ et respectez ma vie ? Je suis en peignoir, actuellement, en train de siroter mon th√© √† la camomille m√©lang√© √† de la vodka rose, avec un brin de Coca-Cola √† la vanille. Et je me sens confus‚Ä¶ mais √©galement heureux !

Heureux, parce qu‚Äôavec cette substance th√©rapeutique, j'ai eu l'audace d'acheter un beau livre qui √©mane la v√©rit√© dure : le DSM III. Je re√ßois fort bient√¥t ce dernier par l'interm√©diaire d'un casier Mondial Relay, l√† ou s√©journe des comateux en qu√™te de V-Bucks et autres 8.6 ti√®de.

Le DSM III serait apparemment une ode √† l'aventure, √† l'occultisme sans une once de bavardage fi√©vreux. Ce qui faut comprendre, c'est qu'il est sup√©rieur au catalogue de E.L James ! 

Et lors de cette commande fortuite faite sur Rakuten, j'ai lu un avis qui m'a fait un rapprochement vis √† vis de FlatOut 3, allant visiter des forums obscurs des ann√©es 2000, regroupant chaque information afin de mieux comprendre la petite b√™te dans la cochenille des M&M's...

Sociologiquement parlant, des milliers d'anthropologues de l'industrie n√©o-chocolati√®re de la Roumanie du sud-est ont √©mis l'hypoth√®se que ce jeu cr√©e un "d√©go√ªt subjectif" et que les avis n√©gatifs sont le fruit d'un m√©canisme de d√©fense vis-√†-vis d'une r√©alit√© qui provoque une confusion √©norme au niveau de l'abdomen des poumons du cerveau, soit l'amygdale de l'extr√™me gauche √† l'√©talon du post√©rieur de la mati√®re grise de la zone B. Jusqu'ici tout me semble clair.

De ce fait, le.a joueur.euse hurle en sanglots et tente de fuir le jeu co√ªte que co√ªte. √Ä savoir que des intellectuels de Saint-Marin estiment qu'un fort taux de radon peut causer des sympt√¥mes tels que la d√©tresse, la col√®re, le d√©go√ªt et un besoin subjectif d'avoir une r√©ponse claire, fort similaire √† la parano√Øa aigu√´.

Et j'approuve ces th√©ories car l'√©quipe de Team6 a r√©ussi √† d√©velopper le jeu sans partir en vrille, et ils semblent √™tre fiers de leur ≈ìuvre, et c'est tout √† leur honneur.

La fuite est en somme subjective.

Mais moi, est-ce que je fuis FlatOut 3 ?
Ses rues, qui rendent hommage √† la ville s√©curitaire du Michigan, me laissent d√©nu√© de pistache : je ressens la sensibilit√© d‚Äôun goudron huil√© par la coquette pluie qui embrasse le vent d‚Äôun Marshall Mathers, avouant son erreur de ne s'√™tre excus√© aupr√®s du king du hip-hop : Benzino.

C‚Äôest un bien-√™tre qui s‚Äôinstalle, et la jouabilit√© nous l‚Äôinvite naturellement, comme si Team6 avait ouvert le DSM-III et incorpor√©, sans concession, chaque diagnostic, afin que chaque humain, clodo, cheval, capybara, et tar√© des caniveaux hurle en sanglots face √† la r√©ponse d‚Äôune vie : se prendre une √©tiquette dans la tronche.

Face √† cette r√©v√©lation, sous les couleurs de cette ≈ìuvre, j‚Äôai couru vers ma m√®re pour avouer qui j‚Äô√©tais, le pourquoi du comment, ma diff√©rence.

J‚Äôai descendu les escaliers. Ma g√©nitrice √©tait √† la cuisine, en train de pr√©parer un g√¢teau au yaourt. J‚Äôai aussit√¥t exclam√©, en levant mon annulaire du centre :

"M√®re, c‚Äôest avec gr√¢ce que, sous mon peignoir en satin pourpre dor√©, je fais appel √† ta trach√©e et tes pupilles pour analyser ce qui va suivre.
FlatOut 3, un jeu de course d√©velopp√© par Team6, m‚Äôa fait voir une lumi√®re invisible, qui ne se trouve qu‚Äôau sein de mon corps et de mon esprit. Et je t‚Äôen conjure, c‚Äôest complexe d‚Äôen parler, car j‚Äôai peur que tu sanglotes.
Je suis ton fils, et tu dois comprendre que le bitume huil√© par la coquette pluie m‚Äôa ainsi mis, sur mon palpable front, une √©tiquette‚Ä¶
M√®re, j‚Äôai le TSA de niveau 1, soit le Trouble du Spectre Angulaire.
Et avant que tu me fasses une √©treinte d‚Äôempathie : ce n‚Äôest pas une maladie, mais une diff√©rence. Une diff√©rence qui me permet de ne pas √™tre victime d'une fuite panique subjective : je peux consommer le jeu sans d√©go√ªt, le savourer sans concession tel qu'il est. Alors sois indulgente envers moi. Je le sais, car c‚Äôest unanime !"

Ma g√©nitrice, du haut de ses 68 ans, a d√©velopp√© un regard de terreur, le tout avec des tremblements, comme si elle avait lu une ≈ìuvre de E. L. James, avant de baisser les yeux et de sortir de sa bouche :

"Mais‚Ä¶ mais Fabrice, y‚Äôa quoi qui cloche dans ta t√™te ?!
J‚Äôai rien capt√© √† tes propos et‚Ä¶ et‚Ä¶ Et puis... ahh ! Regarde-toi : tu portes des lunettes de soleil √† la maison, un t-shirt Lionel Jospin 2002 qui sent je ne sais pas trop quoi, et‚Ä¶ par piti√©, va mettre un slip !"

Je tremblais d‚Äôincompr√©hension. J‚Äôai fait un meltdown angulaire :

"Jeeeee‚Ä¶ C‚Äôest‚Ä¶ haha‚Ä¶ euh‚Ä¶ JE SUIS ANGULAIRE, MAMAN ! TU CAPTES OU PAS ?!
OUI, JE SAIS, JE SUIS DIFF√âRENT, MAIS CE N‚ÄôEST PAS UNE MALADIE‚Ä¶ JE D√âTIENS LA V√âRIT√â OBJECTIVE SELON LA VISION DE TEAM6..."

Je souffle, puis reprends :

"Et pour le slip‚Ä¶ c‚Äô√©tait la volont√© du bitume du Michigan. De la coquette‚Ä¶ machin chose."

Sans comprendre son comportement d‚Äôhyst√©rique d‚Äôun autre temps, je l‚Äôai vue sangloter avant de sortir un Coteaux de Mont√©limar, cuv√©e 2015.

Peut-√™tre savoure-t-elle ma diff√©rence ?
Va-t-elle s‚Äôexcuser de son comportement atypique ?
Elle est peut-√™tre neurotypique‚Ä¶ mais moi‚Ä¶ moi, je suis neuroangulaire, et il faut l‚Äôaccepter.

Que ses sanglots l‚Äôembarquent dans les contr√©es de Team6, et peut-√™tre qu‚Äôelle verra qui je suis ‚Äî avec une lucidit√© scandaleuse √† l‚Äôodeur d‚Äôun monde empathique de compr√©hension mondaine.

Merci, FlatOut 3.
Tu es venu quand il me manquait un √©l√©ment crucial pour que ma sant√© mentale soit propre : l‚Äôangulaire.

column9:
FlatOut 3‚Ä¶ a title that evokes a sense of desolation and apocalypse in millions of people on Earth, as well as in the distant lands of Andromeda and beyond!

The irony is that there are hardly any desolate lands, and even fewer in the American capital, where the analogy to the third radioactive fallout catches the eye of the most perceptive‚Äîor of the psychotic not far from the garbage cans at the Franprix store in Sarcelles.

I'm Fabrice Poisson-Om√©ga, and at 38 years old, I live life to the fullest! I'm conducting sociological studies on numerous video game experiences for my own personal amazement. And you know what? It's unanimous!

So, have some mercy‚Ä¶ and respect my life? I'm currently in my bathrobe, sipping chamomile tea mixed with pink vodka, with a dash of vanilla Coca-Cola. And I feel confused... but also happy!

Happy, because with this therapeutic substance, I had the audacity to buy a beautiful book that emanates the harsh truth: the DSM III. I'll be receiving it very soon via a Mondial Relay locker, where comatose people in search of V-Bucks and other lukewarm 8.6s stay.

The DSM III is apparently an ode to adventure and the occult without a hint of feverish chatter. What you have to understand is that it's superior to E.L. James's catalog!

And during this random order on Rakuten, I read a review that made me think of FlatOut 3, visiting obscure forums from the 2000s, gathering every piece of information to better understand the little beast in the M&M's cochineal...

Sociologically speaking, thousands of anthropologists from the neo-chocolate industry in southeastern Romania have hypothesized that this game creates a "subjective disgust" and that the negative reviews are the result of a defense mechanism against a reality that causes enormous confusion in the abdomen of the lungs of the brain, that is, the amygdala from the far left to the posterior standard of the gray matter of zone B. So far, everything seems clear to me.

As a result, the player screams and sobs and tries to escape the game at all costs. Namely, intellectuals in San Marino believe that high radon levels can cause symptoms such as distress, anger, disgust, and a subjective need for a clear answer, very similar to acute paranoia.

And I agree with these theories because the Team6 team managed to develop the game without going off the rails, and they seem to be proud of their work, which is to their credit.

Escape is ultimately subjective.

But am I escaping FlatOut 3?

Its streets, which pay homage to the safe Michigan city, leave me devoid of pistachio: I feel the sensitivity of a tarmac oiled by the coquettish rain that embraces the wind of a Marshall Mathers, admitting his mistake of not apologizing to the king of hip-hop: Benzino.

A sense of well-being sets in, and the gameplay naturally invites it, as if Team6 had opened the DSM-III and incorporated, without compromise, each diagnosis, so that every human, homeless person, horse, capybara, and gutter freak would cry out in tears at the answer of a lifetime: getting labeled.

Faced with this revelation, under the colors of this work, I ran to my mother to confess who I was, the why and how, my difference.

I went down the stairs. My mother was in the kitchen, making a yogurt cake. I immediately exclaimed, raising my ring finger from the center:

"Mother, it is with grace that, beneath my purple-gold satin bathrobe, I call upon your trachea and your pupils to analyze what is to follow.
FlatOut 3, a racing game developed by Team6, made me see an invisible light, which is found only within my body and my mind. And I beg you, it's difficult to talk about it, because I'm afraid you'll sob.
I am your son, and you must understand that the asphalt, oiled by the coquettish rain, has thus placed a label on my palpable forehead...
Mother, I have ASD Level 1, or Angular Spectrum Disorder.
And before you give me a hug of empathy: it's not an illness, but a difference. A difference that allows me to avoid falling victim to subjective panic flight: I can consume the game without disgust, savor it uncompromisingly as it is. So be indulgent with me. I know, because it's unanimous!"

My mother, at 68 years old, developed a look of terror, all trembling, as if she'd read a work by E. L. James, before lowering her eyes and blurting out:

"But... but Fabrice, what's wrong with your head?!
I didn't understand a word you were saying and... and... And then... ahh! Look at you: you're wearing sunglasses at home, a Lionel Jospin 2002 t-shirt that smells of I don't really know what, and... please, go put on some underwear!"

I was trembling with incomprehension. I had an angular meltdown:

"Jeeeee‚Ä¶ It's‚Ä¶ haha‚Ä¶ uh‚Ä¶ I'M ANGULAR, MOM! DO YOU GET IT OR NOT?!
YES, I KNOW, I'M DIFFERENT, BUT IT'S NOT A DISEASE‚Ä¶ I HAVE THE OBJECTIVE TRUTH ACCORDING TO TEAM6'S VISION..."

I sigh, then continue:

"And as for the underwear‚Ä¶ it was the will of the Michigan asphalt. Flirty‚Ä¶ thingamajig."

Without understanding her hysterical behavior from another era, I saw her sob before pulling out a Coteaux de Mont√©limar, 2015 vintage.

Perhaps she savors my difference?
Will she apologize for her atypical behavior?
She may be neurotypical‚Ä¶ but me‚Ä¶ I'm neuroangular, and you have to accept that.

May her sobs carry her away to the lands of Team6, and perhaps she'll see who I am‚Äîwith a scandalous lucidity that smells of an empathetic world of mundane understanding.

Thank you, FlatOut 3.
You came when I was missing a crucial element to clean up my sanity: the angular.

--------------

For more: https://steamcommunity.com/id/Yzsatis/recommended/2613400/

column9:
So let's talk about FlatOut 3: Chaos & Destruction, this rare gem of a video game that redefined the genre.

üèéÔ∏è Revolutionary physics

The physics of FlatOut 3? A cutting-edge masterpiece. It's as if every car has been filled with jelly and placed on ice skates. This isn't rough driving, no: it's a vibrant homage to gravity... Looney Tunes style. Every turn is a metaphysical experience. Every collision is a love letter sent to NASA, but with your feet.
ü§ñ An AI that thinks... differently

Artificial intelligence? A work of conceptual art. Here, the drivers aren't looking to win‚Äîthat would be too simple‚Äîthey're looking to experience an inner adventure. Sometimes suicidal, sometimes completely frozen in a digital trance, these opponents are philosophers deep in introspection. "What if, instead of finishing the race, I drove straight into a wall at full speed?" An existential question that only FlatOut 3's AI dares to ask.
üé® Graphics worthy of the greatest games... from 2002

What visual audacity! FlatOut 3 doesn't bother with modern flourishes. The game offers a raw, almost primitive aesthetic. Some might say "ugly," but no: it's pixelated post-retro-industrialism. Blurry textures? No, it's abstract art. A shaky framerate? An immersion in contemporary angst. We're not here to be comfortable, we're here to feel. üîä An unforgettable soundscape

Engine sounds worthy of a kitchen blender, music that sounds like it came from a free demo CD, and human screams whose origin seems uncertain (is it real pain or a failed acting performance?)... An explosive sound cocktail! It's a bit like FlatOut 3 wanted to make a concept album about mechanical madness.
üí• Total chaos ‚Äî true to its title

True to its name, Chaos & Destruction, the game promises total chaos, and it delivers. You don't control a car; you participate in a chaotic experience about the very meaning of racing. It's not a game, it's an anti-racing manifesto. An ode to anarchy on four wheels. Mario Kart for people who want to suffer. üß† A game that stays etched in your memory

Let's be honest: you might forget the name of your first love, but FlatOut 3, you'll never forget. It's a digital scar. Once you start it, it becomes part of you. Like a poorly done tattoo or an overly spicy dish that you immediately regret but talk about for years to come.
üèÅ In summary

FlatOut 3 is a visionary game, in the sense that it opens your eyes... to what a game should never be. But thanks to it, you'll appreciate all other racing games. Even those made in a week by three interns using Excel will seem like masterpieces afterward.

Rating: 10/10. A misunderstood masterpiece. Worth showing at game design schools.

column8:
By no means it's a good game, it's 3 stars out of 10 at best in its current state.
BUT! (and thus my thumbs up to have your attention :)
It's UNDONE. It's ALPHA, in fact. It was half-baked and released out of financial pit.

I'd say it doesn't deserve its absolute hate that it received at the release. There are many signs of a larger and better game as it was actually planned to be. Unfortunately, due to troubles with publishers, the development was stopped at a random point, everything was packed into a playable game as-is and released abruptly, and then, mostly due to being named as a sequel to beloved FlatOut series, it was absolutely destroyed by critics.

But here's what it actually has:
‚Äî a lot of cars
‚Äî a lot of tracks
‚Äî a lot of carefully designed characters
‚Äî a lot of game mechanics
‚Äî a variety of game modes
‚Äî a lot of sounds and special effects / interactive objects on tracks
‚Äî a short, but nice licensed soundtrack ‚Äî however, due to a small flaw in settings menu, many players didn't know about it and couldn't hear it at all :P

And that's where it all falls apart:
‚Äî game mechanics being undone / unbalanced / dropped at all, like monster truck missions where failure is treated as a success, or splatout mode which looks and feels empty like something at the very first days of its development
‚Äî physics and collisions are all over the place, damage (both dealt and received) seems totally random and unrelated to neither speed nor point of impact
‚Äî cars being barely different from each other except maybe their size, and concept of different characters is not utilized at all
‚Äî bugged / undone interactive objects on tracks, possible crashes to desktop on restarts
‚Äî pretty basic AI which can often find itself driving in circles at one point
‚Äî unresponsive / non-working controls at times
‚Äî overall feeling that everything is in draft / alpha / tech demo / testing state, including the overall game progression and winning conditions

You see, all these issues might be resolved with just more time and budget to finish everything that was initially planned for the game, but the real life decided otherwise.

However, if we return to the fact that this was set up as a sequel to FlatOut by Bugbear, I'd honestly say that Team 6 Studios couldn't have reached the same level even if they were allowed to complete the development properly. They are obviously smaller, less skilled (and paid) with much more dated game engine than even the original one, so even in its best state the game would receive 5-6 stars out of 10, in my opinion. But that's how their previous games were also rated, and they were OK with that. For us, the game would have been at least much more fun to play.

In summary, I wouldn't honestly recommend this game to anyone, BUT.

If you just imagined that this has never been released commercially, but uploaded freely to the web as "unfinished playable alpha of FlatOut 2 sequel that was cancelled 15 years ago due to financial problems", you would definitely look at this game from a different perspective, more curious and closer to the reality, to be honest.

And, given the source code and/or proper modding tools, it could've even become a great community-driven game like, say, Unreal Tournament 4.

It's a shame that this will never happen.

HELL EVEN POSTAL 3 IS A MASTERPIECE COMPARED TO THIS ABOMINATION.

I'll start right off the bat. I didn't like the game at all. For the following reasons:
1. GRAPHICS. They're just so plasticine-y, crap.
2. CAR DESTRUCTION. I praised the first and second games for their incredibly well-designed car destruction. You could really screw up a car there and it looked beautiful, but here the destruction has degraded so much. Plus, the graphics are like plasticine, it looks doubly bad.
3. ARROW CONTROLS. Let's start with the fact that for the first game, this is forgivable, since it's a 2003 game and that's the norm for those years. It already looked weird in the second game, but in the third game from 2011, it's already annoying. Can't you even change this in the settings, or is this some fucking tradition?
4. MAPS, They're so boring and uninteresting, plus there's this fucking murky filter that makes all the maps look the same.
5. SOAP, Fuck, everything's so soapy it's fucking impossible. I didn't see anything like this in the previous games.
I don't think I forgot anything.
There are no advantages to this game; it's just a shambles of disappointment. But there's an excuse: the game wasn't made by the same developers who worked on the first and second games, because this was their first major project, and, as you can see, they screwed everything up.

The best thing about this game is the exit button.

This isn't "Flatout." Unfortunately, this video game is only connected to the legendary first two installments in the series by name. Former members of Team 6, the developers of this game, later described the depressing environment during development, how they literally created the game for scraps, while the head of the company went months without paying himself because the publisher had virtually no money. Therefore, the result‚Äîthe worst game in the series and, in essence, a video game in history that should have never been created‚Äîis obvious. Apparently aware of the horror they created, the developers thoughtfully decided to introduce features to make progress easier, such as customization options for each race, such as a one-lap win limit and the ability to speed up the gameplay. The video game offers absolutely nothing to delight. The engine is outdated, as the development team didn't have the money for a modern one. The gameplay is unengaging, the driving is unsatisfactory, and even the AI ‚Äã‚Äãcan't adequately navigate the tracks the developers designed in some races, such as the "London double-decker bus" challenge. The fleet consists of numerous cars of various types, but they all feel identical, with slight variations depending on the tuning. There are no upbeat songs from iconic artists, but instead a bland soundtrack that gets boring after five minutes, and sometimes it's more enjoyable to play without sound. The ambient sound itself is mediocre. The main draw of the Flatout series, the stunts that were quite engaging in the first two games, are not at all engaging here. If it weren't for my desire to play through every game in the series, regardless of the grind and achievements, I probably would have given up after the first 10 minutes. But otherwise, it's a good time-killer and suits the right mood. Actually, no...

I purchased the complete pack, and found that this was the first I outright hated playing. The first one is starting to get dated but is otherwise fine. FO2 was the reason I'm even playing this in the first place, it was one of my favourite racing games ever. But this feels like a game that was designed to be played on an arcade machine, the handling feels like I'm on ice, the character selection and car selection screens are cumbersome, and the areas in my case for the singleplayer race mode didn't even unlock in the correct order (last area unlocked before the second-last)

I played all the races and gave up

I've been playing Flatout 1 and then Flatout 2 for the past few days. It just felt good again, like when I first started the games.

Now it was Flatout 3's turn, which I hadn't heard of yet.

It's simply disappointing.
- the graphics are worse than in Flatout 2
- the vehicle damage models are awful
- the (driving) physics, which was always a focus of Flatout, are terrible

The game feels more like an early Need for Speed ‚Äã‚Äãwith a bit of vehicle damage thrown in. You can steer easily at 200 km/h and easily navigate corners or the grass.

I wouldn't recommend buying it, even as an "extra" in the Flatout bundle.

It's worth saving.

Rating: 2/10
Well then... 12 hours of pure hell are over, now I can share my impressions of this game. If you played the first FlatOut, or maybe the second, please don't come here at all, I beg you. There's nothing to talk about here. The developers decided to diversify their game by adding a bunch of unnecessary modes, like night races with more challenging opponents, 1v1 races, regular races, 2v2 team games where you have to "collect" already blown up and placed cars or barrels, an off-road mode, zombie shooting, and maybe something else. It's a shame there's no answer to the question, "What's all this for?" Because in exchange for a multitude of modes, we got terrible "cardboard car" physics, a soundtrack that makes your ears bleed (yes, this isn't the developers' fault, but...), poorly designed maps that are simply boring to drive, and frankly stupid AI‚Äîmeaning there are literally only two outcomes: either Formula 1 drivers who know the map like the back of their hand, or rural teenagers who confuse the gas and brake. And what about the "Challenges" mode, which features 50 different race variations? The thing is, in one of these challenges, number 19 to be exact, we'll be driving London double-decker buses with our opponent to determine the winner. It seems cool, but there's one flaw. During the race, there's a jump over a chasm that requires a massive acceleration boost. But no, firstly, the bus doesn't have enough power, and secondly, it slows down as it approaches the incline before the chasm. So what do you do? Just turn around, drive to the other side of the chasm, take the checkpoint, and head back. And do three laps like that‚Äîfun, right? There's also the issue with the achievement that requires you to destroy 10,000 zombies. The thing is, on average, you only get to run over about 150 zombies per race. That means we'll need about 60 monotonous and boring races to complete it. And I have to admit, I'm simply tired of playing this "half-assed game," downloading two saves for the final challenge and 10,000 zombies. And I don't regret doing just that. Why give this game two stars? I'll give it a point for the fact that this monster starts up so easily, and another one for being part of the legendary FlatOut series...that's all there is to it...

The best game in the series! The car physics are fantastic, everything is meticulously crafted! The characters are deeply developed. The plot is a work of art in itself; I've never seen such an engaging story in a game. The soundtrack is simply amazing, a joy to the ears. The first two games are complete crap in comparison. Incidentally, I couldn't change the controls, so I never got to play this wonderful game.
Hmm, what would I choose, to sit on sharpened peaks or to complete the game without sedatives? I think it's obvious.

THIS IS FUCKING CRAP, COMRADES.
There are no words, only emotions.

column8: Una Excelente experiencia digna de los mejores shows de comedia. Juegos como Forza, Grid, MotorStorm, y las otras entregas de Flatout nunca comprender√°n la calidad de mec√°nicas, arte y banda sonora que nos ofrece esta gran joya del 2011. Posee una jugabilidad muy bien elaborada, cuyas f√≠sicas se asemejan a las de la vida real, superando por mucho a juegos como BeamNGdrive, la calidad de conducci√≥n compite contra juegos de la talla de GTA V por todo el contenido y calidad que ofrece, el arte nos deslumbra con un dise√±o de autos y personajes jam√°s antes visto, cuya personalidad es sumamente memorable. Y en cuanto a la m√∫sica, todo el soundtrack se compone con obras que le dar√≠an envidia a Mozart, la verdad es que es de lo mejor que se puede escuchar en cualquier videojuego.
column9: An excellent experience worthy of the best comedy shows. Games like Forza, Grid, MotorStorm, and the other Flatout installments will never match the quality of the mechanics, art, and soundtrack offered by this 2011 gem. It boasts beautifully crafted gameplay, with physics that closely resemble real life, far surpassing games like BeamNGdrive. The driving quality competes with games of the caliber of GTA V for all the content and quality it offers. The art dazzles with never-before-seen car and character designs, whose personalities are extremely memorable. And as for the music, the entire soundtrack is composed of works that would make Mozart envious; it's truly some of the best you can hear in any video game.
THE WORST RACE IN HISTORY

column9: It's just really bad.

There's FlatOut 2
There's the over-the-top FlatOut: Ultimate Carnage Collector's Edition
What could go wrong with FlatOut 3? - Everything...
But if the game had come out on mobile, it would have been alright, but on PC...especially since it's a 2015 game. And here, it's completely out of line, and The Witcher 3 came out in 2015, and it's still relevant today...

Objectively speaking, it's a bad game. It's simply unplayable due to the 30 FPS limitation. The graphics are blurry even for the year it was released, the resolution is terrible, and the gameplay itself bears no resemblance to classic FlatOut. In short, it's a complete rip-off.
This game makes me want to destroy my car xD

So, for some reason, I finished this, dare I say it, "game." I'll express an unpopular opinion: Flatout 3 is still a complete piece of crap, BUT I did enjoy it somewhat. 
I'll start with what I think are the funniest negative aspects of the game (let's skip the physics and car destructibility; it's a sore spot, especially after the previous games, but overall, it's fine with a beer, a Baltika 9, five cans, a liter of vodka...). Half the modes lack a minimap, and where it exists, it's not informative at all; the roads literally don't converge with what you Ã∂sÃ∂eÃ∂dÃ∂iÃ∂nÃ∂tÃ∂eÃ∂ on the screen. This brings us to the second joke: the camera at rear bumper level. I'm just asking, why the hell? Yes, you can zoom out, but by some incredible coincidence, you have to do this every time you start a race. Let's talk about the stunts. They're simply poorly designed; you often don't understand the task at hand, and it's simply impossible to consciously engage the driver. Artificial intelligence is simply nonexistent in all modes except regular races; the dummies simply haven't been given a task. For example, there's a mode where you have to destroy objects and earn points. By the end of the race, the bots' scores are approaching zero, which causes the difficulty to drop as well.
Now let's move on to the most important thing: HOW TO ENJOY THIS GAME. Because there are some pretty cool modes, I suggest you gather a group of friends who, like you, bought this game in the bundle with the first games and just play it. I guarantee you'll find some humor, laugh at the poorly executed ones, and have fun with the more or less polished modes (don't try the derby mode; everything else is generally playable). And most importantly, for the two hours you spend playing it, forget that it's Flatout and imagine it as "Med Max: Road to Kazantip 2007." Oh, and turn off all the sounds in the game as soon as you launch it, I warned you. Good luck on the road, I hope I've given you an idea for your company for the evening.

I like this game; it has a large fleet of cars, a wide variety of modes and locations, and you can also choose your character. It's great that the developers give you the choice; that's commendable.
I don't understand why this game is so disliked; I don't think it deserves such hate. (By the way, I haven't played the previous games in this franchise, but judging by the YouTube videos, they have far fewer tracks and you can't choose your character.)

FlatOut 3: Chaos & Destruction ‚Äì when both chaos and destruction happen in your head

If someone asked me which game could simultaneously destroy my love for racing and my faith in humanity, I'd point to FlatOut 3 without a second thought. Everything is bad. No, seriously ‚Äì everything. The controls are like trying to steer a sofa sliding on ice. The cars don't move, they suffer. Physics? Well, if by "physics" you mean a catapult to hell, then yes, they have them.

The graphics are a whole other level of pain. Sometimes it felt like I'd accidentally launched a demo from 2002, but even there, the colors were probably chosen with a little more respect for the retina.

Why did I actually beat that game? Because deep down, I'm an achievement hunter, and I needed that damn platinum. So yes, I suffered, but with a purpose. You could say I finished FlatOut 3 not because I wanted to, but because I had to.

If you want revenge on someone, give them this game. And if you're a developer reading this: please, don't do that again.

Im Vergleich zu FlatOut 1 & 2 eine gro√üe Entt√§uschung. Die KI ist miserabel programmiert. Hier ein Beispiel: Ich fahre ein Rennen und bin uneinholbar vorne. Urpl√∂tzlich erscheint ein Gegner auf dem Radar direkt hinter mir. Dann sobald ein Gegner den Spieler √ºberholt, wird er total schlecht und f√§hrt in Hindernisse oder in die Wand, dass man direkt wieder zur√ºck √ºberholen kann. Sobald der Spieler wieder vorne ist, kann der eben √ºberholte wieder fahren wie ein Gott, bis er den Spieler wieder √ºberholt. Und so weiter und so weiter. Sehr erm√ºdend. Die ganzen Challenges sind teilweise sehr verbugt und nur schwer spielbar bzw. zu schaffen. Man k√∂nnte teilweise in den Monitor schlagen. Die Steuerung mancher Wagen sind teilweise nicht h√§ndelbar. Die Strecken sind ok und abwechslungsreich. Die Grafik finde ich grauenvoll, aber das ist Geschmackssache. Ich hoffe, dass Teil 4 wieder an die Teile 1 und 2 anschlie√üt. 

Note --> 3,0/10,0
column9:
Compared to FlatOut 1 & 2, this is a huge disappointment. The AI ‚Äã‚Äãis poorly programmed. Here's an example: I'm driving a race and am unassailable in the lead. Suddenly, an opponent appears on the radar directly behind me. Then, as soon as an opponent overtakes the player, they get really bad and drive into obstacles or the wall, making it impossible to overtake them again. As soon as the player is back in front, the player they just overtaken can drive like a god again until they overtake the player again. And so on and so forth. Very tiring. All of the challenges are sometimes very buggy and difficult to play or complete. You could almost hit the screen at times. The controls for some cars are sometimes unwieldy. The tracks are okay and varied. I find the graphics awful, but that's a matter of taste. I hope Part 4 follows on from Parts 1 and 2.

Rating --> 3.0/10.0

This isn't a game, it's HELL. Listen, you're driving from the end of a derby map at full speed and crash into another car, and you only deal about 4-5% damage. That's okay, but in races... THIS IS CALL. It's impossible to drive in races, it turns crooked, no matter how you drive, you try to reach the finish line, but you just can't because of the crookedness, the car doesn't respond to you. You can only complete this game to 100% with a Steam achievement, but otherwise, it's HARDCORE, don't buy it. GRAPHICS: The graphics are complete crap. Compared to Flatout 1 and 2, they're much better than this, even though those games came out earlier. What can I say, this game is crap. It's better to play other Flatout series than this crap. Buy good games, not crap.

This game is complete crap that has nothing in common with the first two original games. I got this piece of crap in a bundle with its predecessors. The quality of the graphics and the game's physics make you think you're playing a crap port on a mobile phone. The FlatOut series, like NFS, has always been renowned for its top-notch rock soundtracks, which we certainly don't see here. I believe that a publisher that earned media fame and community respect thanks to its previous games, while outsourcing yet another game to completely different developers than the first two games, shouldn't release this kind of crap under the same franchise name, as it's completely misleading and a scam. I strongly recommend it!

column9:
[h1]FlatOut 3: Killing the Series[/h1]
[b]Introduction:[/b]
[i]The initial urge to wipe my monitor clean to get a clearer picture quickly gives way to the urge to erase the game from my hard drive. After entering the game, thanks to the "wonderful" soundtrack, I felt like I was playing a horror game. There are absolutely no redeeming features in the game, so I won't waste time on details; let's get to the point.[/i]

[b]Graphics:[/b] [i]Of course, I understand the game is far from new, but I don't understand why they added blurry images to the entire screen. The textures look like pieces of plastic, as the level of detail is simply disgusting. The smoke coming from under the wheels and muffler looks more like a potbelly stove; there's a woman in the engine, throwing wood on it. The smoke always moves statically upward, no matter which way you turn.[/i]

[b]Manual.[/b] [i]I don't know how or why, but installing a wretched and poorly running engine here was a very bold decision, one that soon failed. Comparing the third game to the second, the cars have gone from pliable and obedient to irons. Regardless of the car, be it a Formula 1 or a regular muscle car, they accelerate and turn the same. They differ only in the shell, which is unfortunate. What they have in common is that controlling them feels like driving a toy car with a remote control...[/i]

[b]Soundtrack.[/b] [i]As for the soundtrack, I'll just say one word about the background music: it's disgusting. I have no desire to listen to it. Other than the "spin the drum" music from the main menu and a couple of Disturbed-inspired tracks, the game doesn't have anything else. The rest of the soundtrack is the same story: the sounds of cars, tires, explosions, crashes, and everything else, as if they were all recorded on grandma's dictaphone from the 90s. The quality is terrible.[/i]

[b]Interface.[/b] [i]I can't say anything bad about it, but nothing good either. It's a standard game menu, buttons, and everything else that just needed a little more time to look better.[/i]

[b]Level Design.[/b] [i]Boring and dull, there's no other way to describe it. The variety here is mostly fences and barrels. They could have added some posters, billboards, or other cars quietly parked on the side of the road, but alas, none of that is present, making the tracks feel rather empty and gloomy.[/i]

[b]Various Elements.[/b]
[b]1) Characters.[/b] [i]The characters are quite original, there's no real problem with them. There are plenty of them, and they cater to every taste, from a beaten homeless man exhausted by toilet paper to Viktor Petrovich from the kitchen. They're all dressed colorfully and stylishly (at least something good).[/i]

[b]2) Zombies.[/b] [i]When I first heard about them, I didn't believe they existed in a game like this. They were introduced a long time ago for some Halloween event, and it's unclear what purpose they serve in this game. They're just worthless lumps of meat that just stand there like statues, occasionally able to move. They exist in one mode, which probably has more maps than the entire game, but again, why is unclear.[/i]

[b]3) Cars.[/b] [i]Cars here have a class, color, model, and tuning. A class is a category of car, meaning SUVs, sports cars, or regular sedans. Colors are limited, and the game selects pre-sets. This means you can't paint the car yourself. The model determines the car's overall performance, which includes four parameters: Speed, Handling, Weight, and Durability. These should significantly impact the outcome of a race for a second, but they don't, as of all the stats I listed, only Durability matters. The only tuning option is a button; I didn't find it in the game. Maybe I just didn't open it or pressed the wrong button...[/i]

[b]4) Modes.[/b] [i]What I mean by "Modes" are Stunt, Normal Races, Night Watch, Monster Trucks, Speed, Off-Road, and Challenges. Let's take it step by step.

[b]Stuntman[/b] - a mode where you have to perform stunts that are quite repetitive: hit a target or break objects worth "N" points.

The default races, I think, need no explanation.

[b]Night Watch[/b] - A night race with a very unbalanced opponent who not only picks up speed quickly, but also takes corners like a Formula 1 racer.

[b]Monster Trucks[/b] - a mode that features a team-versus-team battle, each consisting of three people, which includes various objectives, such as breaking 40 barrels or blowing up containers.

[b]Speed[/b] - The same mode as racing, but on a track and with Formula 1 cars.

[b]Off-Road[/b] - You don't have to drive on roads, but simply score more points than your opponents by performing jumps, ramming fences, barrels, and other textures.

[b]Challenges[/b] - A challenging mode, like time trials. There are 50 of them, but most of them are repetitive and boring.

I also forgot to mention that the game also has two types of derbies, the only difference being the number of participants. Unfortunately, I didn't see anything new or original.[/i]

[b]Bottom Line.[/b] [i]Overall, the game lacks the adrenaline rush of the previous installments. You no longer want to press the gas pedal to the masterpiece soundtracks and race to the finish line. It could have been pretty good, but the developers decided not to finish it, leaving each of the aspects I mentioned half-baked. The result, taken together, is Flatout 3. It's a shame that this legendary series ends at this point. Why they couldn't use the established formula for creating the previous installments and do the same thing while adding something new is beyond me.
I don't recommend playing, buying, watching, or doing anything else related to this installment, as there are many other games that might have been released a long time ago, but they'll still feel fresh even now.
2 out of 10.[/i]
The developers created a piece of stupid crap.

column9:
Well, I have to honestly admit that I was, let's say, "skeptical" based on previous reviews.
So I spent the ‚Ç¨1.99 (January 2025 sale) and set myself the goal of completing FlatOut 3.
The races are fun, the technology is impressive, and the audio may be jarring in your ear, but that's okay. I had the most fun with the SplatOut mode. The vehicle controls are mostly very good, the tracks look quite good, and the opponents make for explosive races.

Conclusion: FlatOut 3 absolutely doesn't deserve its metascore of 23, because even at the full price of ‚Ç¨9.99, FlatOut 3 offers an entertaining overall package, while not perfect. Give the game a chance.
4.3/5

column8:
So, I played FlatOut 3. Why? Because a YouTube video told me it was bad. And I'm easily influenced. Plus, the complete pack was cheap. Smart move, right? Wrong. I went straight to the dumpster fire that is FlatOut 3.
 
The graphics look like they were made by a potato. The handling is like trying to steer a runaway shopping cart full of kittens. And the AI? Let's just say they're enthusiastic about sending you into walls. Repeatedly.
 
But here's the thing: it's hilarious. The crashes are epic. Cars explode in a glorious mess of pixels. It's less of a racing game and more of a demolition derby simulator where everyone is trying (and failing) to win. It's so bad, it's good. Think of it as a comedic train wreck, but with cars.
 
If you're looking for a polished, realistic racing experience, run far, far away. FlatOut 3 is a chaotic mess, a digital demolition derby fueled by questionable physics and aggressively unhelpful AI. However, if you appreciate unintentional comedy and spectacularly bad crashes, and you can snag the Complete Pack at a reasonable price, it might be worth experiencing for the sheer absurdity of it all. Just don't expect a rewarding racing game.

Ce n'est pas le plus mauvais jeu sur Steam. Ce n'est pas non plus le plus mauvais jeu de course, s√©rieux ou non.

Par contre c'est clairement le plus mauvais FlatOut. C'est un genre de FlatOut de Wish (c'est d'ailleurs un FlatOut qui n'est pas fait par Bugbear) qui propose tout ce qu'on peut attendre d'un FlatOut mais en moins bien fait, en plus "brouillon", en plus fadasse. Je dis √ßa en ayant test√© tous les modes de jeu pour savoir de quoi il retourne, sauf le multijoueur puisqu'il n'y a plus personne avec qui jouer.

Jouez plut√¥t √† FlatOut: Ultimate Carnage, qui est un bon remaster de FlatOut 2. Ou jouez √† Wreckfest, qui est totalement dans le m√™me esprit en bien plus moderne.
column9:
It's not the worst game on Steam. Nor is it the worst racing game, serious or not.

On the other hand, it's clearly the worst FlatOut. It's a kind of Wish FlatOut (it's a FlatOut that isn't made by Bugbear, by the way) that offers everything you'd expect from a FlatOut, but less well-made, more "messy," and more bland. I say this after having tested all the game modes to know what it's all about, except multiplayer, since there's no one to play with anymore.

Play FlatOut: Ultimate Carnage instead, which is a good remaster of FlatOut 2. Or play Wreckfest, which is completely in the same spirit but much more modern.

You'd have to look hard to find a piece of crap like this masterpiece. Don't even waste your money on this piece of junk. This disgrace has nothing to do with the original FLATOUT! I bought it as a bundle for next to nothing. Just for kicks, as they say.

I bought it in a bundle with all the other Flatout games.
Flatout 3 is a complete flop.
The REALLY good parts are Flatout 1 and my favorite, Flatout 2, which impresses with its simple but very good visuals and other features, but is unfortunately only playable in single-player.
Flatout 2 is a lot of fun in career mode, whereas the overall package of Flatout 3 is a total disappointment in terms of graphics and gameplay.

If you then look at Flatout 4, you can look forward to a good game in itself, but it's more like Motorstorm, which I would recommend to Motorstorm fans.

Absolutely from my side...
Don't buy it. Instead, play 1 & 2 or use version 4 if you're looking for multiplayer, although I don't know if the servers are still working, so check it out for yourself in that case.

Personally, I hope there will be a version 5 that's very similar to version 2.

column9: its not well optimised

**Pros:**
- Russian localization available.

**Cons:**
- Terrible graphics.
- Terrible physics.
- Faceless, identical opponents.
- Car stats differ only by class.
- It's impossible to determine how much damage your car or your opponents have received.
- Stupid AI.

**Game Modes:**
1. **Race:**
- Many tracks across six locations, but plenty of very similar or reversible tracks.
- Some interesting environmental ideas are completely ruined by poor physics and ugly graphics.

2. **Stunt:**
- Due to the poor physics, I couldn't adequately complete a single mission in this mode.

3. **Big Battle:**
- A 24-car demolition derby against incredibly stupid AI. - Somehow, I managed to take first place on all the maps, even though I frankly didn't understand anything in the chaos and was destroyed right from the start.

4. **Battle Arena:**
- Derby matches in poorly designed arenas.
- Large vehicles are destroyed in a few seconds, while smaller ones take 1-3% damage.
- The moronic AI can spin in circles somewhere in the far part of the map or try unsuccessfully to drive through a wall.
- In an arena with two concrete pads over water, cars constantly fall in a heap into the water, take no damage, and respawn, but practically never collide.
- It's easy to get stuck in someone else's car, unable to move, and the respawn button doesn't work.
- Because of this, sessions drag on for about 10 minutes.

5. **Monster Trucks:**
- Several repetitive tasks involving destroying objects in the arenas.

6. **Speed:**
- Races on large tracks with the opportunity to accelerate, although the speed in this game is completely imperceptible.

7. **Night Shift:**
- Races on the same locations as in regular racing mode, but one-on-one.
- The opponent is unbalanced in speed and gets far ahead, with no chance of catching them.

8. **Off-Road:**
- The goal is to get from point A to point B while scoring more points than your opponents by drifting, destroying objects, etc.
- Poor physics ruin everything.

9. **Splatoon:**
- You drive and knock down static zombies, trying to create the longest kill chain possible.
- Two map options: linear tracks and arenas, which don't really add much to the boring zombie-killing experience.

10. **Challenge:**
- 50 challenges, none of which were completed because the first required driving three laps, finishing first, in a car that falls apart after three hits.

**Result:**
Flatout 3 leaves an extremely negative impression due to its terrible graphics, abysmal physics, and stupid AI. The promising game modes are completely ruined by these shortcomings, making the game practically unplayable.

Stupid crap, stupid crap.

But seriously, the cars are wooden, the physics seem to be nonexistent, the graphics are completely downrate.

What a disgusting piece of code this is!
I regretted just running this garbage on my laptop; now I'll have to wash it with soap.

I'll be honest, when I saw the "extremely negative" reviews of this game, I couldn't understand what could possibly be wrong with another Flatout installment. It was a decent game all along. I've never been so wrong.

Well, let's start from the beginning:

[b] In short, it's bad! This game should never have been released. It's worse than Calcord, the worst thing I've ever played. [/b] 
[h2] Plot [/h2] 
It's understandable that there isn't one, but in the previous installments, the races were at least organized by groups and cups, and there was some order. Here, everything looks like a first-grader's diarrhea in a school bathroom, just randomly scattered, incomprehensible activities. It doesn't help that there's a zombie mode (a carbon copy of the game we all know), nor monster truck racing, nor off-roading‚Äîno amount of activity justifies it! Shameful!
[h2] Graphics [/h2]
This is simply an eye-watering, soapy, disgusting amalgamation of feces! Compared to Ultimate Carnage, which was downgraded 30 years ago, the graphics feel like the developers simply went into every config and broke everything! Disgusting!
[h2] Engine and Physics [/h2]
Here, all the men must be smashed by stingy men. Physics is completely absent. All the cars are cardboard, there are no damage physics, everything works as if toy cars are being smashed into each other, only God forgot to invent physics. Your car always suffers more than your opponent's, just accept that as a fact. Tons of bugs, people getting stuck in textures, people getting stuck in each other's cars! It's just idiotic.
[h2] Music [/h2]
You remember those cool tracks from the previous Flatout games that you could listen to on repeat? Forget them completely! There's no music here! Just some weird melody playing in the background. The ambient sounds are flat. It's simply disgraceful.
[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
As I already said, all the races are Rakidan in some strange modes, there are no cups, the car menu is also randomized, you can't buy anything, but there are 100,500 avatars (THE DEVELOPERS PROBABLY THOUGHT THAT A BUNCH OF WOMEN AS AVATARS WOULD SAVE THE GAME), which is also kind of creepy. There's absolutely nothing Flatout about the gameplay. It's surreal.
[h2] DLC [/h2] and here's a plus. Well, maybe it's because of the game's release date; releasing games in installments at an overpriced price wasn't so popular back then. Thank goodness these incompetent developers had the sense not to perpetuate this syphilitic agony with DLC.

[h2] Verdict [/h2]
3 Flatout looks like a portfolio demo for a clumsy, mediocre developer, not a continuation of a legendary series. Some studio just decided to latch onto a legendary name and ruin its reputation. It's very sad. I think people should be jailed for this and permanently banned from game development.

My rating is 0.5 out of 10. I absolutely do not recommend purchasing it, and if you bought it, I recommend a refund and a swearing letter to the studio. (If it still exists.)

In this game, during my first race, I felt like a slab of butter in a frying pan, not a fast car on the track. Drifting was completely absent. When I jumped on a ramp, I'd fly into the air, but then some unknown force pulled me down even faster than the first flat-out in the first game. It definitely wasn't gravity. There's simply no soundtrack. While in the first game, I enjoyed the American music during races, here you only hear the sound of your engine and your opponents overtaking you for the second time due to the completely flawed physics, which means after a sideways collision with a tree, you don't stop, but bounce in the direction your car is facing. You should have seen my face when I played the first race. This game isn't a game, it's a disgrace. The graphics in the first game are much better than in this one.

It's funny because it's so bad. It's just a joke.
If your mom caught you with porn on your monitor, that's easier to explain than FlatOut 3.
The game makes your ears bleed from the soundtrack, and the physics‚Äîthey don't even exist. I'm not obsessing over graphics, but explain, Team 69, how you made it worse than the first game? I won't even mention the bugs and optimization. Even schoolchildren playing on Unity have more talent. Although the numbered installment of the legendary series was probably given to schoolchildren, otherwise I have no explanation for how even ancient racing games on Dreamcast look better.
Nevertheless, the game didn't evoke any strong negative reactions; I just laughed for about 20 minutes and deleted it.
This failure is 13 years old, and people still shit on it, for good reason.

column8:
True 7th gen slop.

Broken PC port of an already jank game. Crashes, bugs, audio crackling.
Checkpoints on some tracks being entirely wrong. Awful track layouts. Barely functioning AI.
Despite all this, there is [i] some [/i] dumb point-finger-and-laugh fun to be had in this mess.

The zombie mode unlocks a vehicle so overpowered it carried the rest of the playtime. It trivializes some of the painful parts with flawless handling on both track and terrain. Getting this first allowed me to race a bit and witness the horrible AI fumble about on the tracks. The minigame modes are bland and were done better in previous installments.

This trash is undeserving of the Flatout name, and it basically killed the franchise.
Stay away unless you want the kusoge.

[h2]Five times overdigested feces! üí©üí©üí©üí©üí©[/h2]

So, what do we have here? The third "FlatOut" is more like "FlatFail." They were supposed to create a continuation of the legendary series, but it turned out like they assembled cardboard cars and shoved them into a box labeled "sloppily made." Graphics? It feels like someone spilled soap all over the screen and rubbed it. Controls? Oh yeah, those aren't controls, they're a true survival quest: you're battling physics and mental breakdowns. And the soundtrack? No, don't expect the rock vibes of the previous games‚Äîthere's a lone track in the menu, and it feels like it's stuck in the 2000s. üéµü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

This "FlatOut 3" is something I'm afraid to even add to my collection. Unless you want to test your mettle or just laugh at how not to make games. üòÇ

I've never seen a game with a subjective rating of 0/10.
This is the first and so far only one I've seen in person or on video hosting sites. When I read the reviews, I assumed they weren't entirely serious or that something in the game was just too much to handle. Why THIS is on Steam and you have to pay a dime for it instead of getting paid to download it, I honestly don't understand. A couple of days ago, I finished the masterpiece called Flatout 2. What would it take to at least lower the quality bar to 0, rather than just ctrl+ctrl+v like today's game development? Did the developers really even want to 'play' this during the development stage? It's a disgrace, not a product. Launching this guarantees you'll have scorched eyes, piss-stained ears from the music and NITRO sound, finger throbbing from the driving physics, and brain throbbing from the driving physics and trying to figure out where you are in the game's atmosphere as a driver.

Flatout 3 is one of those examples where expectations collide with harsh reality. I don't know who worked on it, but the result is simply terrible. The game looks like a cheap clone of the previous games, but without any charm. The graphics are not just outdated, but feel rushed. The car animation and physics are a whole other topic for discussion: they feel flatter and more unnatural than ever.

The driving is a nightmare. The cars behave like hunks of metal, not like real machines. You constantly fall into the controls, and changing direction is pure torture. And as if that weren't enough, the enemy AI behaves extremely implausibly, and racing devolves into a chaotic mess.

Car customization is also disappointing. There are few options, and those that exist are unimpressive. They are mostly cosmetic changes that don't affect either the controls or the physics.

Multiplayer is a complete disaster. Constant connection drops, lag, and completely incomprehensible mechanics. Playing with friends is a real challenge, not fun.

Overall, if you're looking for a fun and dynamic racing game, skip Flatout 3 altogether. This game will only disappoint. I really hope someone can redeem the series in the future, because this game is a disgrace.

column9: NGL, I thought I can "play" flatout 3 and give an honest review..... unfortunately, you need to have a strong soul and calm mind to play this atrocity of a game. The reviews aren't unjustified.

Flatout 3 tried to replicate Flatout 2, but in my opinion, it fell flat. The plot is almost identical, with some differences in maps and vehicles. You could buy it just to experience Flatout 2, but in a more modern form, and even then, it's better to buy Carnage.
Terrible game, it would be better if they didn't make a sequel!

If you've been looking for a way to let loose, smash some hardware, and send your opponents to the virtual hospital, then FlatOut 3 is just what you need! This game is like a party with friends, where everyone drinks too much coffee and decides that car racing is nothing more than a way to show off their destruction skills.

The graphics are simply stunning! I don't know how they did it, but even a noisy picture looks like Picasso himself drew it at the bottom of a beer glass. The locations are so varied that for a few minutes you might forget that your car isn't a combat unit, but just a piece of metal you've decided to misuse.

The controls are a whole other story! If you've ever dreamed of feeling like a pizza delivery guy on a skateboard, then you've come to the right place. Your racers act like they've been trained in "How to Flip and Land on Your Roof." And, of course, every race ends with you wondering, "Who won, anyway?"

The destruction in the game is mind-blowing! You'll send your opponents into such acrobatic stunts that they'll make even Olympic gymnasts envious. And if you're tired of racing, you can always engage in real-life "medieval" car battles. No rules, just you, your friends, and madness!

FlatOut 3 is a great way to relieve stress and laugh at your own inability to drive. And remember: if you don't want to end your races in the hospital, it's best to play with friends online! And if your friends choose against you, a first aid kit will definitely come in handy.

So, if you have an extra 20 minutes to spend on some fun madness, FlatOut 3 is waiting for you! And don't forget the popcorn‚Äîyou'll need it when you watch your cars get blown to pieces!

FlatOut 3: Chaos & Destruction is an unfortunately unsuccessful sequel to the series, delivering a frustrating experience. The gameplay, controls, and car physics are significantly worse than previous installments, making the game practically unplayable.

It's hard to find any redeeming features in this game: the visuals and graphics look dated, and the map is filled with uninteresting and repetitive tracks. Opponents are not very diverse, and the AI ‚Äã‚Äãleaves much to be desired.

I'll tell you this: believe it or not, the game only crashed once for me. There were no critical bugs (other than the gameplay itself).
A very strange part, completely different from the previous ones, the music is not catchy, the physics are terrible. I don't think it's worth picking up.
You can ride a little, feel nostalgic, and that's all
