column9:
Flatout 3: Chaos & Destruction is a 3D racing game full of destruction, explosions, and mayhem. There are tons of vehicles and modes to choose from. Everything starts with setting the number of opponents, game speed, and damage multiplier, making each race your own, as nothing is predetermined. There are several maps with different variants, and of course, the maps have various shortcuts and traps that add variety to the races. Besides races, there are deathmatches, ragdoll minigames, off-roading, challenges, and much more. There's even a (functional) multiplayer mode if anyone's interested. You can earn all the achievements. ‚úÖ
I liked it, I recommend it üëçüòé

He didn't cut my veins, he didn't gouge out my eyes, he even walked in

"A man dies and goes to hell. The devil meets him and says, "Well, you haven't sinned much, so you can choose your own torture."
And he shows him three rooms.

In the first, people are boiling in a cauldron:
-No, don't bother with that.

In the second, people are being stabbed with pitchforks.
-I don't want that either.

He opens the door to the third room, and there are men sitting at their computers, smoking and eating chips:
-Oh, that's just it. I'll take it.

He enters the room and sits down at the table, when suddenly someone says, "Okay, guys. Smoking break's over, let's continue playing FlatOut 3."

P.S. This is a "why didn't you become like your older brother?" game. I was hoping to see FlatOut 2 updated for our times with improved graphics, but in reality, I saw nothing but improved graphics. Three crashes out of 10.
This is such crap, how could it be worse than the second part?

column8:
[h1]I do not recommend anyone buy this game[/h1]
First of all, the game has awful physics, not mentioning that cars do not feel like cars at all, it's some sort of carts that can't properly turn. 
Secondly, car sounds are ridiculously loud when played in 3rd person but cannot be heard on bumper camera.
The damage meter here probably the most strange thing to analyze.
You bump into a guy in full speed?
He takes 5% damage.
You slightly touch him, he still takes 3-5% damage. there's no speed-damage mechanics.
I did try to play it, but it's just not pleasant enough to try to. So... yeah that's it.

It's just bad, not the whole franchise but this particular game.

column9:
I bought this series when the bundle was on sale. 
Given the review score, I'm willing to buy it out of curiosity. It's probably a little better than that legendary car game. 
This game apparently has 10 game modes, but I heard that Speed ‚Äã‚Äãmode is the most decent, so I played it a couple of times. 
Some say the controls are too difficult, but you can still drive at a reasonable level by using boost in straight lines and slowing down appropriately when turning corners. 
However, the game doesn't slow down at all even when driving on dirt roads (shoulders), allowing for unlimited shortcuts, making it a complete failure as a racing game. 

The other modes are hardly worth praising. I haven't played all of them, but with this review score, that's probably why. 
One positive is that it supports high resolution for a game of this era (2011) and has no FPS cap. 
However, if you're just looking for fun, you're better off buying a modern game.

column8: Una aberracion como destruyeron el juego
column9: An aberration how they destroyed the game

Let's do a review after a full playthrough.

1. Broken levels. I'd like to see at least working levels (the ability to unlock offroad levels), but they didn't even add that. Although if you use an old save, you can play it.

2. Career. It's missing. I'd like it, after all, this is a continuation of the first two games, which had one.

3. Level variety. This would be a solid plus, if not for a few quirks.
- Classic races (day and night) are pretty cool, but only until you realize the cars' trajectories are scripted. This means that bots will perform better on dangerous turns than you. It's especially annoying when you miss a turn on a night track simply because the bot beats you to it.
- Rally. Two races can't be unlocked, and instead of regular races, you get something like a Pure version where you have to perform stunts. Cool, but... the drift category? Buggy?.. But at least you can get a lot of points in destruction.
- Cars. No questions asked.
- Stunts. Quite easy but interesting. No questions asked. Somehow even better than the first games (and definitely better than Part 4).
- Zombies. It's a plus that this mode exists and the zombies are mobile. But it feels like you're destroying boxes because their speed is practically zero and they can spawn in the air.
- Challenges. Sometimes they're fun, a couple are quite challenging, and one (at night) is almost impossible. Thank you. It makes you work hard.
- Monster trucks. This raises a lot of questions. It's not your opponents who hit you, but your allies. Opponents and allies alike can sometimes spin in one place. You're the only one completing the objective. You're the default winner even if you lose. You can be destroyed before reaching the objective, which is trivial. Overall, it's very, very debatable.
- Derby and Grand Derby. This is where the biggest questions arise. Because the physics have changed, you now take damage not only for force but also for the duration of collisions, and the part of the car you hit has no bearing on it. Plus, when you accelerate into an opponent, you can take more damage than they do. It's a real shame it didn't turn out like in parts 1 and 2. A real shame.

4. Localization
It's there, but sometimes it's funny. Porpalla GT. What is that? It sounds funny. At least Detroit was translated adequately.

5. Soundtracks.
This is a major downside. The music is turned off by default, and for good reason. The car sounds are awful. The tracks, too, without lyrics, are uninspiring to listen to more than once. If you turn it off completely and turn on your own, it will be much better. Driving to classic tracks from CrashDay, NFS MW, and Flatout 1 and 2, humming "Hey-yey-yey-yea" from the classic games, is much more enjoyable.

6. Graphics.
If I'd seen it in 2013, I would have been horrified. But in 2024, it's almost nostalgic. Plus, there's a 4K mode. Thankfully, it's not so eye-popping. True, it prevents vertical sync from working and the game crashes, but oh well...

7. Controls.
Quite classic, a bit rough, arcade-like. Sometimes you miss a turn. The main issue is with the bots, who follow a script and are sometimes faster than you because of it. At forks in the road, they always choose the same direction.

8. FPS.
Another plus is playing the game at 400 FPS in 2k24. Optimization.

9. Multiplayer
You can find a room. Enough for an achievement. Then the game crashes for the host.

10. Achievements.
You can get everything (if you unlock off-road levels and reverse tracks), no big deal.

Conclusions.
I still wouldn't recommend it. The game crashes occasionally at random times. Plus, it changes the graphics in Windows, maybe making the font small, for example. But you can still enjoy it; it even gave me a nostalgic feeling.

column8: Worst of the series so far.  It's just frantic to the point where it's not fun anymore.  Handling is worse, massive rubberbanding, no upgrading cars and no career mode anymore so there's really no progression or reason to keep playing.  There's more race modes but only 4 tracks per mode.  Most of the cars in each class are exactly the same with different skins.  It's like they tried to add so much stuff that they took away from what made these games fun in the first place.  Played a couple hours and got a headache... uninstall!
column9: Worst of the series so far.  It's just frantic to the point where it's not fun anymore.  Handling is worse, massive rubberbanding, no upgrading cars and no career mode anymore so there's really no progression or reason to keep playing.  There's more race modes but only 4 tracks per mode.  Most of the cars in each class are exactly the same with different skins.  It's like they tried to add so much stuff that they took away from what made these games fun in the first place.  Played a couple hours and got a headache... uninstall!

It's not that it's completely unplayable (the handbrake controls are even interesting), it's just not clear why. This would have looked strange even in the 2000s.
The physics of sliding boxes; there's no career: there's just a bunch of tracks, but they're pretty mediocre. Derby is essentially nonexistent, given the lack of a proper damage model‚Äîit's just boxes smashing into each other on the field.

I completed the first night track and got a gold achievement for it, which should say a lot (good things) about our society xd

column8:
If you really think that FlatOut 3 was the worst game ever, then you clearly don't know much about games in general. 

Look folks...

I've played other Team6s' games like 'German Street Racing', 'European Street Racing', 'French Street Racing', 'Glacier Racing' (aka Tesco Ice Racing), 'Glacier 2', 'Glacier 3', 'Amsterdam Taxi Madness' and 'TaXi 3 eXtreme rush' :)

At the time of its release this was probably the best and most ambitious title in the whole Team6s' history! 

It is trash, a trainwreck, and an abomination of a racing game... but it's also so utterly ridiculous that I just had to try one more race... and then one more... and maybe one more XD 

After few tries I started to actually get it, and won some races. 
Weird feeling - at first I was ready to toss this game aside at any moment, but it started to win me over a little bit, with the sheer amount of absolutely hilarious stuff happening basically every race. 
It was NOT boring - and that's already better than FlatOut 4 ;p

 I noticed that there's a really significant difference between cars, when it comes to handling and performance. 
Most people say they all handle like trash... but... there is a peculiar appeal to all of that trashness :) 

At the end of the day - I had a suspiciusly good time with this game ;p But, well - try at your own risk :)

column8: Flatout 3 is flat out the worst racing game I have ever played. And I've played Big Rigs.
column9: Flatout 3 is flat out the worst racing game I have ever played. And I've played Big Rigs.

In the library, the background of this game shows a man thrown out of a car, covering his face with his hands. I don't think you'll find a better reaction to this game. Because it's just a "facepalm." Even the pilot himself doesn't want to see this disgrace! He's ashamed to be playing this game! And I feel sorry for him, because I played it too.

This is nothing like FlatOut in name alone. I've never seen such trash.
I thought the NFS series had gone downhill, but even they didn't produce such garbage back then.

Everything about this game is terrible: the controls, the music, the physics, the graphics (it was 2011, by the way, and the textures are cardboard, as are the weather conditions, which hurt my eyes (the rain looked like laser beams from a spaceship, and definitely not drops of water, but bombs!)). They seemed to try to add variety to the tracks, but everything else outweighs the previous shortcomings.

I kept thinking I was playing a Unity mobile game, but no, it's a computer game from 2011, but it feels like it was made in 2000. It's like it was made concurrently with the original FlatOut, and they decided to release it seven years after the first game.

2 facepalms out of 10!
I didn't expect that this part of the legendary Flatout series would come out... Physics, graphics, design... Simply awful.

Flatout 3 is the best game in the series!
The first time you launch the game, you're greeted with a brown sound, emphasizing the epic nature and seriousness of this video racing game.
We're presented with a ton of characters with interesting backstories to choose from, highlighting the meticulous work of the writers. Just look at the story of the girl from the North Pole with her brain frozen. :)
The third installment features even more interesting game modes, such as: Race, hit the target outside the camera's view, Battle Royale, another Battle Royale, another Battle Royale, find the tiny pixel on a giant map, a Formula 1 simulator, and even a rival to the great Left4dead.
Many call the physics in this game broken, but I'd call it hardcore, the envy of any racing sim.
The minimalist graphics, reminiscent of Carmageddon, are also worthy of praise, which is a definite plus. In conclusion, Flatout 3 is unfairly overrated and a hidden gem in the gaming industry. I recommend it to everyone. 9.5/10

I think anyone who tried the third game hoped they'd enjoy it, if not as a continuation of the famous franchise, then at least as a racing game in its own right. I thought the same thing, that perhaps players didn't like the change in concept, which they perceived as a betrayal, and that the third game itself was fine as simply a different racing simulator. But as it turns out, the game isn't bad because it's a completely different game‚Äîthat is, Flatout 3 has nothing to do with the FlatOut series‚Äîit's bad simply because it's bad. It's simply a poorly made racing simulator, regardless of its title.

At first, it took me a while to get used to the controls and the need to use the handbrake, but soon I was able to complete track after track quite easily. The problem was, I was doing it almost automatically, without any real pleasure. That rarely happens to me. Even free university projects (not all of them, of course) piqued my interest, but here I played without any enthusiasm, as if I was forcing myself through the game. Yes, the game is easy to complete, but... it's just not engaging. And it's not engaging because... there's nothing interesting here, not a single interesting element.

Cars. As someone rightly pointed out, these are more like toy cars than the real thing, which even the first FlatOut had. Furthermore, there's no destructibility of the cars, nor is there any destructibility of the environment, or, more accurately, the feeling of a destructible environment. A simulation of destructible objects was created, but it looks like the destructibility from computer games from 2000, where strictly defined and extremely limited objects explode, like barrels or parked cars. Therefore, it would be fair to say that there's no destruction in the third game. And how could it be otherwise, when we have toy cars here that offer minimal, barely visible damage. It seems to me that the damage to the cars is directly proportional to the destructibility of objects on the track itself, i.e. Objects located on the track that can be interacted with through direct contact (scattered boxes, plastic tables and chairs, etc.).

The locations or quality of the designed tracks. They fit harmoniously into the overall concept of the game, but as tracks, they are terribly designed (often straight lines with sharp 90-degree turns). But even this wasn't the tracks' biggest flaw for me. The main drawback is the terrible information about where to turn. I was constantly turning (or not turning) in the wrong places. We all remember that one of the main features of the second FlatOut was the numerous alternative routes, but here this option seems to be absent, or hidden so deeply in these chaotic, painted tracks that you need to dedicate a single race to exploring the location to find the hidden alternative route (I only found such a route once, and even then, I can't bring myself to call it a "good alternative"). And that's not to mention the fact that the computer never used this approach. Add to this the horribly implemented active environmental objects, like the attack helicopter that constantly fires at one of the track zones, or the moving trains we have to navigate between. The concept may be interesting, but since the game itself is terrible, it doesn't really help an initially bad game even reach the average level. Just as the cars are toy-like, so is the helicopter. The insanity of the landscape, which makes us feel like we're on a roller coaster, adds an arcade feel, but at the expense of realism (the very same realism that gives us the destructibility so beloved by many).

Compared to this, the graphics, tuning (which is practically nonexistent), sound, car control, opponents, and everything else pale in comparison, and even these elements look terrible. As I wrote at the very beginning, every element of the game is terribly implemented. I don't think the problem lies specifically in the racing car style, but in the way it was implemented. Yes, Flatout 3 is radically different from all the other installments, and in that sense, the third FlatOut offers something new, but that "something" is literally everything, as absolutely nothing remains of the classic FlatOut. But even this new implementation is half-hearted. The extremely negative rating (16%) is well-deserved.
Direct proof that you shouldn't let dubious studios make big projects.

column8:
Es incomprensible c√≥mo consiguieron hacer este juego tan mal. 
Los controles mal, los coches se sienten que flotan y siguen girando a la vez que pesados y lentos en los giros. 
Los da√±os que haces son un misterio divino (embestir a otro coche a 200Km/h suele hacer menos da√±o que rozarlo en la parte trasera, suele porque es consistentemente inconsistente) y esto parece que aplica a todos los modos de juego, lo que lo hace super doloroso en los derby (o como se llame en este juego).
Las acrobacias son un chiste tambi√©n, al lanzar al personaje tiene la misma probabilidad de salir disparado para delante que hacia los lados.....

En fin, es un juego sin gracia, sin alma y aburrido (excepto por la IA que a veces con el "rubber banding" alcanza velocidades supersonicas y los pi√±azos son legendarios). 
El √∫nico motivo para tener este juego es cogerlo en paquete con el 1 y el 2.
column9:
It's incomprehensible how they managed to make this game so poorly.
The controls are poor; the cars feel like they're floating and keep spinning, while also being heavy and slow in turns.
The damage you do is a divine mystery (hitting another car at 200 km/h usually does less damage than rear-ending it, usually because it's consistently inconsistent), and this seems to apply to all game modes, which makes it incredibly painful in derbies (or whatever it's called in this game).
The stunts are a joke too; when you throw your character, they have the same chance of being launched forward as sideways...

Anyway, it's a dull, soulless, and boring game (except for the AI, which sometimes reaches supersonic speeds with rubber banding, and the crashes are legendary).
The only reason to own this game is to get it in a bundle with the first and second versions.

column8:
Nope, this is not a joke: I give thumbs up .... here is why: people who love Flatout 1 & 2 can't expect a successor racing game. Physics, damage model, drifting, crashing ... nothing comes close to a somewhat "realistic" action racer. Flatout 3 is pure Arcade racing - when breaking, the car drives like on a rail track.  It looks and feels like "Flatout -10" ten years before the first version.

But I had to race a few rounds and as I threw away my expectations of a better Faltout 2, it was somehow funny because it was so retro arcade racing fun. The music is cool, the graphics is a strange mix of comic, cell shading, dirty looking comic and the audio and video effects are somehow retro. So, it's not plain bad if you can feel some love for arcade racers and are open to the style of Flatout 3. It's just not a "Flatout 3" sequel but a whole different game.

And it also runs on Linux (with Proton Experimental). :-D

column9: better than the second part

For some reason, I bought this, achieved all the achievements except for the multiplayer, and I have something to say. I'll go over every aspect of the game.
Physics: It feels like it was made with Unity Web Player or Adobe Flash. Collisions with opponents are completely unenjoyable because they're implemented incredibly poorly ‚Äì you hit someone at full speed and lose a surprising 1% of their durability, a little more, or even 0%, while simply touching a wall or the slightest impact can cause you to lose a full 10% or more.
Nitro in this game isn't so much a boost as it is a car repair tool. Yes, you heard right, nitro in this game repairs your car. This is a feature mentioned on the loading screens, though the very "high-quality" translation makes it a bit difficult to understand.
Car fleet: It's not small, it's quite varied, and that's a fact. I'm still trying to figure out why F1 cars handle like crap. There are many modes, and most of them are varied, and that's a fact. I'll go into detail:
Stunts: They're still there. However, some of them are frustrating to play due to the awkward camera tracking the driver. Additionally, you can't influence the driver's flight path forever, because once the "Aftertouch" bar runs out, your opinion is no longer taken into account by the game, and the driver flies where he was originally going.
By the way, male drivers moan with the sound of a woman. I don't know if this is a bug or a feature; after all, we live in progressive times.
Splatout: Crush zombies that don't even move. It fits this game perfectly if you consider it a standalone game, but it doesn't fit the Flatout series.
Monster Trucks: Playable. However, due to the very "high-quality" translation, it's a bit difficult to understand what to do in the "Let There Be Light" level. Here's what you need to do: Push any nearby barrel into a container. By the way, I don't quite understand why you can select any other class of vehicle in this mode, not just monster trucks. Incidentally, you can simply skip all the monster truck levels‚Äîjust crash, and you'll still be credited for completing them (why this is possible is unclear; perhaps the game hasn't been tested).
Off-Road: It's just there and it works.
Night Shift: Races on tracks from the "Race" mode, only at night, in the rain, with near-zero visibility and poor traction. Some tracks play fine, while others are worse due to the large number of fog and rain effects on the screen.
Speed: Why you can select any other class of vehicle in this mode, not just racing cars, is unclear. There's nothing to say about that, and I've already commented on the racing cars.
Challenges: Some of them will be quite a challenge. By the way, here are some free tips for completing some of them: Turn around and drive backwards before the ramp in Challenge 19, which is practically impossible to jump over even at "Fast" game speed; Change the game speed to "Fast" for the stunt challenges (why do they even let us mess around with the game speed?); Change some values ‚Äã‚Äãin the game files so your opponents crash on the first turn, because beating them fairly is basically impossible, in Challenge 30 (see the discussions, there's a question about this challenge, the answers include instructions on what and in which files to change).
Derby: The worst derby you can play.
Racing: By the way, the tracks in this game are pretty good.
Music: When you enter the game, you're greeted by music from hell (or from hell, or from ZAD ‚Äì that's a good question). It's mostly crap, but there are a couple of listenable tracks and even one gem ‚Äì "Bring it Down" by Redshirt Theory (by the way, check out the music video for it, you'll smile) and its second version.

Conclusion: Like Flatout, it's a bad game. Perhaps if it had a different name, it wouldn't have gotten so much flak. Is it playable? - Well...maybe. If you buy it on sale for 38 rubles, turn off your brain, and imagine it's called something else, you might get some...umm...perverse, peculiar pleasure playing it. At least it's better than those gacha games on mobile that drain your wallet dry; at least there's gameplay here (perhaps that's the biggest compliment I can give this game).

I won't criticize the game too much, as I played it after the first two parts and one expansion to the second, albeit a standalone game.
Of course, there are many downsides, from the missing physics to some logic in scoring in some modes.
I won't criticize the developers, as the game was made almost entirely out of pure enthusiasm, as the development time and budget were cut. Of course, the developers wanted to add everything and more, but they ended up with just that, and a lot of quality was lost in the process.
I recommend the game purely to collectors. Feel free to skip it.
But if you do launch it, go straight to zombie mode. I don't recommend any other modes, or it's up to you.

column9: This is a terrible version of Flatout, it has nothing good compared to the second version.

Well, I don't know, it's a great game for me! Before joining the army, I decided to play this third FlatOut of yours, just to see what it was like. After completing it, the military recruitment office declared me insane and didn't draft me. Now I'm in a mental hospital, relaxing :)

Seriously, this is one of the worst games I've ever played. I knew beforehand that this gaming product wasn't particularly well-received, but I decided to play it anyway. I played it. Not just played it, I completed it 100%. My mouth is still soaked with feces, it was delicious. Even in 2024, looking through the prism of all the crap that came out after FlatOut 3, it's trash. It's trash among trash.

The first thing that catches your eye is the graphics. The graphics are simply atrocious, worse than the first fucking game. And this isn't a joke, it's not an exaggeration, it's not an overstatement. The graphics here are truly worse than in the first game. You can compare the screenshots of the first and third games for yourself. Where there's pure clutter and terrible texture quality, it's the third game.

The second thing that's noticeable is the lack of music. There's none outside the main menu. An arcade racing game supposedly full of unbridled fun and destruction of everything that can be destroyed has no music. Seriously?

Okay, after I finished the game, I read the reviews and noticed that it turns out there is music in the game, it's just turned off by default. I went into the settings, and it turns out that in the sound settings, next to the music, you need to change "Game Music" to "Custom Music" or something like that. I launched the first race to test it, and yes, the music appeared. I wish it hadn't appeared, my ears are still bleeding. The music somehow broke the game sounds; everything started groaning and farting. The "music" itself is crap.

The third brick of this brown construction is the driving experience and physics. There are no race cars here, no CARS at all; here you're driving toy cars, the kind every little boy played with as a kid. Although even TOY cars have better physics than the cardboard ones here. Controlling them is extremely difficult and unpleasant; turning is a pain in the ass, constantly crashing into things.

The fourth circle of hell here is the track layout. The tracks are terribly configured; apparently the studio that developed this masterpiece had no testers, and the developers themselves were too disgusted to play their brainchild. Constant 90-degree turns, sometimes it's hard to tell where you're going. At high speeds, you're looking not at the minimap, but at the road, which sometimes simply lacks landmarks, or if there are, they simply blend in with the surroundings. I especially remember the bus test vividly. Briefly, there's a certain section of the track that climbs up a hill and ends with a ramp. The only problem is, the bus is heavy, so driving up the hill, let alone over the ramp, requires speed, which this bus doesn't have. There's no nitro either. There's no room to pick up speed; the straight section of track before the ramp doesn't allow for the necessary speed, and before that section, there's a straight turn. I struggled with this for 10-15 minutes until I came up with an idea. My only opponent was similarly stumped before this ramp and couldn't do anything, so I calmly crashed into him, and the nitro came back. I drove halfway back on the map, gained some speed, tried to negotiate my favorite 90-degree turn a couple of times, and finally, with the help of nitro and God's help, I managed to get it in and jump over. Who. Fuck. This. Tested. Oh, I already answered that question: nobody. By the way, the opponent kept stumbling on that ramp while I was grinding out all three laps.

The fifth detail of this garbage titan is all sorts of minor flaws, like falling through textures, buggy AI opponents that can constantly respawn in a certain corner, and the almost completely abolished tuning. Tuning is nominally present here, but in reality, it's not. "Tuning" is represented by two or three free options that are available from the start. The first option is the default car. Everything is self-explanatory. The second option is a heavier and more durable, but also slower, option. The third option is the opposite of the second, a more fragile yet faster car. There's no currency like in the previous games, nor are there any parts that can be purchased with that currency. Right, why bother with a tuning system when you can skip it?

And now the funniest part: after completing the entire game, I found some positive aspects to this underbelly! Hey, what kind of mental hospital? What kind of mental hospital?! What kind of mental hospital?! What kind of mental hospital?! Who are you calling?! So, here are the positive aspects. There's a decent selection of cars, even a tank! You can now choose your driver, and there are plenty of them, including a couple of funny, meme-worthy ones like the local Vin Diesel. However, these drivers don't affect ANYTHING, although something could have been invented. There are a decent number of modes, from good old races, demolition derbies, and various driver tricks, to new ones that sound pretty good on paper. Simple monster truck quests (shoot down 40 barrels, push a mine to the sewer, etc.), high-speed car racing, a decent zombie mode, and night racing. The track visuals are occasionally cool, and there are some interesting gameplay elements, like helicopters firing at certain sections of the track or, say, moving trains you have to squeeze past. Sounds cool! There were some interesting ideas! It's just a shame these ideas aren't built on the solid foundation of the second game, but on a puddle of piss and shit.

Why didn't I say anything about multiplayer? I think that question doesn't need an answer; it's all pretty self-explanatory.

To sum it up: I don't recommend this game to anyone who values ‚Äã‚Äãtheir time and mental health under any circumstances. For fans of trash and garbage like me... well, God be our judge.

Obviamente que a tarefa n√£o seria f√°cil para a Team 6, afinal o sucesso dos jogos anteriores era enorme, e tinham um nome  muito forte pra carregar. column9:
It's undeniable how disastrous this game is compared to the previous FlatOut games developed by Bugbear. Obviously, the task wouldn't be easy for Team 6, after all, the previous games were hugely successful, and they had a strong reputation to carry. The fact is, FlatOut 3 is inferior in practically every way, lacking the adrenaline and fun that made you spend hours playing without getting bored like its predecessors. The game fails to convey the sense of achievement and the desire to finish it, as it offers no incentive to do so. There's no money or mechanical customization, the music is just one or another, constantly repeating, the graphics, destruction effects, and lighting are poor, and the gameplay and physics are horrible, as the cars look like paper, and they behave disproportionately, lacking any sense of realism.

What's interesting is the variety of cars and game modes, as well as the option to choose characters (not that this makes any difference in gameplay), and the multiplayer is quick and straightforward.

It's a good way to pass the time; it's worth buying if there's a good sale.
It's so bad that I'm stuck in the menu.

column9: Flatout 3 is a game from 2011 and the next part of the legendary racing series Flatout and the successor of the legendary Flatout 2 or its better version Ultimate Carnage. This installment is known for being the worst installment in the series, even the lowest rated game on Steam. And this designation is fully deserved. So first of all, the steam page of the game tells you that Czech is not supported as the language of this game, but as soon as you install and run the game, it is in Czech. For being from 2011, the game looks absolutely hideous graphically, even on ultra details. The game has several categories of races, of which max 2 are good. Formula and Splatout mode, which is just running over zombies, which you can't spoil too much. Although I don't know about the creators of this game. This part was no longer made by the original studio, but by a completely different one that had absolutely no idea how to make a racing game. Classic races are completely unplayable here. The cars go at least 200 km/h, you and the enemies have a constantly refilled turbo, which the AI ‚Äã‚Äãlikes to abuse. The cars are uncontrollable and you can't turn them properly. Tuning is almost zero, except for one possibility of modifying the vehicle's properties, which will make an already uncontrollable vehicle even more uncontrollable. The main thing is that there are a trillion characters to choose from as drivers. The maps are unnecessarily long and full of turns. There is also a stunt mode. There are a few here, but most of them are about the same thing, which is to shoot the driver and hit the target right in the middle. And there are very few maps here. Demolition derby mode is a chapter in itself. That's probably the worst thing about this game. One game will take you at least a quarter of an hour, even if you run into an enemy at full speed, you will give him a maximum damage of 3%, or he will not get a hit, or you will just take away your health, as soon as several enemies pile up on you, you are just driving, because they turn you sideways every time. In the 24-player version, the first player drops out after 6 minutes. And then there are Monster truck and offroad modes. But I've only tried those once and like the rest of the game they're bad. The career mode is supposed to be here, but I haven't explored it further. I have about 80 minutes on the game, which is more than I want to invest in this game. I only have the game thanks to the fact that I bought it in one package, which included all parts of the series, except for four. Avoid this game by all means, it's a real cesspool. 0/10

A man dies and goes to hell. The devil meets him and says, "Well, you haven't sinned much, so you can choose your own torture."

And he shows him three rooms.

In the first, people are boiling in a cauldron.

"No, don't take that one."

In the second, people are being stabbed with pitchforks.

"I don't want that one either."

He opens the door to the third room, where some men are sitting at their computers, smoking and eating chips.

"Oh, that's just it. I'll take it."

He walks into the room and sits down at the table, when suddenly someone says, "Okay, guys. Smoking break's over, let's continue playing FlatOut 3."

column8:
I am going to write a 100% honest review with no bias and a completely open mind:

Positives:

     1: When you load onto the game, it uses music from your music folder, so you can choose whatever songs you wanna listen to. +1 point

     2: There is a large variety of game modes that one may find enjoyable, and that adds a lot of re-playable content. +1 point

     3: There is a large list of cars that are each unique in their own way, and you have lots of freedom in the car choice for each event. +1 point

     4: There is ingame stat tracking which is nice to know how many events you win/lose etc. +1 point

     5: The game runs at high framerates even on potato systems. +1 point

     6: The crash physics are nice. +1 point

     7: The events have lots of carnage and destruction. +1 point

     8: The AI is very forgiving which can make it easier to win if you are new to racing games. +1 point

     9: The cars feel fast. +1 point

     10: This game can help with video game addictions. +1 point

Negatives:

     1. When you load onto the game, the volume is so loud that even on the lowest settings you can't hear your friends over the game. Sometimes when you restart events, you will get ear-raped with literal train station sounds. Other times, it just sounds like you are getting a particle accelerator beam shot through your eardrums. -3 points

     2. In the "race" gamemode, sometimes you forget that you are in a race because the AI suck that much. In the "stuntman" gamemode, you try to eject your person into different areas, like mini golf. The game doesn't tell you where to aim, you have to find out yourself. In the "battle arena" gamemode, the AI will only target the player. You don't win a demolition derby from being last alive, you win by getting the most points. "Big battle" is just like the battle arena but bigger, and whenever the AI start to push you, you cannot move and it is inevitable that there will be a large pileup. In the  "monster trucks" gamemode, you aren't forced to use a monster truck. In the "speed" mode, the cars cannot even make it past 150mph. "Nightshift" is a gamemode where you 1v1 an AI during a foggy and rainy night. The AI can turn on a dime and you cannot see the road. You cannot win, it is near impossible. The "offroad" gamemode is a racing gamemode where you win by getting the most points, the cars cannot make it past 70mph either. "Splatout is a zombie gamemode, where you kill zombies to win. The zombies have no AI, they don't move, they just stand there. "Challenge" is a gamemode that is just the other gamemodes, randomly selected with a random car. The other gamemodes suck, therefore this one sucks too. -19 points (-10 for each mode, and an additional -9 because challenge is all the other modes combined)

     3. The only customization is color and two premade performance kits on very specific cars. No body kits, no nothing. The car models are ass too. -3 points

     4. The ingame stat tracking doesn't work. For reference, the game says that I have 124 hours on it (not true) and says that I have lost 175.2447052002 races. I don't know how I lost a fraction of a race, I don't know how one could fuck something up this bad. -4 points

     5. A blind person would be offended with how bad this game looks. My friend could count the polygons on his fingers. He is quadriplegic, he cannot use his fingers. This game actively hurts my eyes. -3 points

     6. You could land on your roof going 100mph and the game wouldn't even crash you. You could hit a pole at 20mph and crash out. When you hit an AI, they go flying at far greater forces than what you hit them with. -3 points

     7. There are so many obstacles on the track that you cannot see the way you are meant to go. The minimap doesn't line up with the road, so you can't even use that. This is not helped by the games graphics. -3 points

     8. I forget that there are AI in some gamemodes, and I remember how bad they are in all the other gamemodes. -2 points

     9. The boost doesn't help with the acceleration. All it does is uncap your top speed and increase your FOV. When you turn, the car goes straight. If you use the handbrake, half of the time it speeds you up, and it also lets you "turn" around a corner. When I say "turn", it feels like your tires are coated in butter and you are on an ice rink, but it also feels like an formula car that is stuck to the ground with an excessive amount of downforce. The grass doesn't slow you down and has the exact same physics as the road. When you jump, the gravity pulls your nose to the ground way more than it should. It is  indescribable how bad the physics are. -10 points

     10. This game is so bad that I have PTSD every time I boot my computer. I cannot remove the icon from my desktop because I am scared that I would accidentally start the game. This game is truly awful to the point where it feels like a punishment to play. -10 points

Final score: -50/10

Final verdict: I do not recommend getting this game. I unfortunately only have the time to write 10 negatives because I scheduled many different doctor's appointments because I am afraid that this game might have given me cancer. I had to divorce my wife because this game gave me aids. This game ruined my life.

column8:
[h1]Flatout 3: Desastre en la Pista de Destrucci√≥n[/h1]

[h2]Resumen[/h2]
Si disfrutas de una experiencia de juego que te haga questionar tus elecciones de vida cada vez que arrancas el motor, entonces Flatout 3 puede ser la mala decisi√≥n que est√°s buscando. Con una puntuaci√≥n que podr√≠a hacer llorar a los m√°s optimistas, este juego es un descontrol con ruedas en un festival de desilusiones.

[h2]Aspectos importantes e interesantes[/h2]
- [b]Crash y Burn Baby:[/b] Si alguna vez quisiste ver tu auto destrozarse en mil pedacitos sin sufrir consecuencias en la vida real, ¬°este es tu juego!
- [b]F√≠sicas Defiantes:[/b] Lo que le falta en gr√°ficos, compensa en f√≠sicas que desaf√≠an toda l√≥gica conocida. Coches que vuelan m√°s alto que tu esperanza de diversi√≥n.
- [b]Variedad de Mods:[/b] Hay bastante variedad de modificadores en el juego aunque la mayor√≠a parece que hicieron m√°s da√±o que ayuda.

[h2]Aspectos por mejorar[/h2]
- [b]Todo lo Dem√°s:[/b] Desde la IA hasta la trama (¬øhab√≠a alguna?), todo parece requerir una reconstrucci√≥n total. ¬øEmpezando tal vez por despedir al equipo de prueba (si es que hubo alguno)?

[h2]Tabla de Puntuaciones[/h2]
[table]
[tr][th]Aspecto[/th][th]Puntuaci√≥n (0-10)[/th][th]Comentarios[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Jugabilidad[/td][td]2[/td][td]M√°s frustrante que intentar armar un mueble sin instrucciones.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Dificultad / IA[/td][td]1[/td][td]La IA parece haber sido programada en una noche de insomnio.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Contenido[/td][td]4[/td][td]Suficiente contenido, pero ¬øde qu√© sirve si no quieres usarlo?[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Video / Gr√°ficos[/td][td]3[/td][td]Visualmente tan atractivo como un choque en c√°mara lenta.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Historia[/td][td]1[/td][td]¬øHistoria? ¬øEso se come?[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Ambientaci√≥n[/td][td]2[/td][td]Como un mal d√≠a en Las Vegas, pero menos glamoroso.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Efectos[/td][td]3[/td][td]Los efectos son lo bastante buenos para saber que algo sali√≥ mal.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]M√∫sica[/td][td]5[/td][td]Adecuada, lo √∫nico que no te har√° querer silenciar el juego.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Voces[/td][td]3[/td][td]Tan inspiradoras como un discurso de un pol√≠tico en campa√±a.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td]Diversidad[/td][/try][td]2[/td][td]Tanta diversidad como en una reuni√≥n de claustrof√≥bicos en un ascensor.[/td][/tr]
[tr][td][b]Total Puntuaciones[/b][/td][td][b]26/100[/b][/td][td]Ouch.[/td][/tr]
[/table]

[h2]Veredicto de Compra[/h2]
[b]No lo compres[/b]

Con el veh√≠culo de tus pesadillas listo para lanzarte a la aventura m√°s frustrante de tu vida digital, recuerda ‚Äî a veces el precio no justifica la experiencia, incluso si solo buscas triturar unos cuantos coches por el camino. Mejor ahorra esos billetes para algo m√°s valioso, como unas buenas palomitas de ma√≠z mientras ves pel√≠culas de acci√≥n de los 90, al menos ah√≠ los efectos son intencionalmente malos.
column9:
[h1]Flatout 3: Disaster on the Destruction Track[/h1]

[h2]Summary[/h2]
If you enjoy a gaming experience that makes you question your life choices every time you start the engine, then Flatout 3 may be the bad decision you're looking for. With a score that could make even the most optimistic weep, this game is a wheel-on-wheels, heart-stopping, heart-stopping festival of disappointment.

[h2]Highlights and Highlights[/h2]
- [b]Crash and Burn Baby:[/b] If you ever wanted to see your car smash into a thousand little pieces without suffering real-life consequences, this is the game for you!
- [b]Challenging Physics:[/b] What it lacks in graphics, it makes up for in physics that defy all known logic. Cars that fly higher than your hopes for fun.
- [b]Variety of Mods:[/b] There's quite a variety of modifiers in the game, though most seem to have done more harm than good.

[h2]Areas to Improve[/h2]
- [b]Everything Else:[/b] From the AI ‚Äã‚Äãto the story (was there even one?), everything seems to need a complete overhaul. Maybe starting with firing the test team (if there was one)?

[h2]Scoreboard[/h2]
[table]
[tr][th]Appearance[/th][th]Score (0-10)[/th][th]Reviews[/th][/tr]
[tr][td]Gameplay[/td][td]2[/td][td]More frustrating than trying to put together a piece of furniture without instructions.[/td][/tr]

Flatout 3: Chaos & Destruction is an exciting game that combines elements of arcade racing and derby. It offers players plenty of opportunities to wreak havoc on the track.

The game's graphics are top-notch, and the destruction physics add a touch of realism. The variety of tracks and game modes will keep even the most experienced players entertained.

However, like any game, it has its drawbacks. Some tracks may be too challenging for beginners, and the controls can be a bit awkward at times. However, these shortcomings don't detract from the overall experience.

Overall, Flatout 3: Chaos & Destruction is an excellent choice for arcade racing fans and those looking to add a little chaos and destruction to their gaming routine. I recommend this game to anyone looking for an exciting pastime.

column9:
Team 6
These best developers in the world are masters of creating electronic gameplay!

Let's start with the main menu, which clearly shows how bad this game is.

The characters differ only in name, and the creators at Team 6 are such pranksters that they decided to create characters as parodies of famous characters.

The game is also a huge disappointment. The cars don't differ in handling at all, and the tuning options are scarce.

We can't upgrade cars like in the previous installments, but we can change the colors to more funky ones. XD

We have to be first in every race. Will you come second? That's a bummer. There are few consolation prizes and medals, you just have to be first, and that's it!
This isn't a game for the faint of heart!

Stunt Mode - Often, you can't eject your unfortunate opponent, which is maddening; completing any stage is a miracle.

Derby Mode - Opponents are programmed solely to destroy us. The most absurd thing is that when an opponent pushes us, we get more points for dealing damage.

Monster Truck - This is a collection of 5 different events. You drive them like they're on ice, and instead of completing the task, the opponents themselves crash into you, making the task more difficult.

Driving Model - Vehicles are controlled like cardboard on ice, and the physics are also broken. Every time you hit a wall, your vehicle bounces like a rubber ball in random places.

You can't see your character when destroying a car! What the fuck is that? A ghost car? So why did they put a man falling through the windshield on the cover? If that's not in this game!

How could they forget about something like that when making "FlatOut"? For fuck's sake?!

Are the bushes made of fucking concrete? (I don't think so.) Every encounter with them ends with the vehicle being destroyed!

Now, the cherry on the cake: the "Artificial Intelligence" ‚Äì the developers have done an exceptional job in this aspect. Often, our opponents don't even notice we're in the game ‚Äì it's a complete mess!

The graphics in this game are a nightmare, the environments are terrible, the models are poor, and the special effects are a joke, plus the most intense blur I've ever seen in a racing game. In a piece of crap like this, the blur is so thick that you can't see anything, not even the track itself (the image looks like vomit).

The car is an earworm. They couldn't even do that, and the engine sounds resemble modified lawnmowers.

The optimization is a disgrace, not when minimizing the game crashes, constant crashes and lag, enemies can't stick to the designated route and get stuck in everything around them, some update with a sloppy Mrs. Santa Claus + a map of Moscow? What's the big deal? Even after downloading it, we don't get the content of this junk in the game!

Team 6 should be punished for cheating players like this. The game fails in every respect:

Gameplay - Sucks
Driving Model - Sucks
Graphics - Sucks
AI - Sucks
Price - Sucks
Screening - Sucks
Audio - Sucks

I can't find any merits to this shoddy work myself.

The only thing that works is the "Uninstall" button on "STEAM."

For this reason, this crap deserves the worst possible rating!

I recommend anyone who has played this for more than an hour to get an autopsy!

This racing game offers incredible excitement and adrenaline, immersing players in a world of speed and competition. Excellent graphics and realistic vehicle physics make this racing game incredibly engaging. The ability to choose from a variety of tracks, cars, and racing modes adds variety and interest to the gameplay. Each race becomes a true test of the player's driving skills, strategy, and reflexes.

Intense battles for first place, dynamically changing weather conditions, and the ability to upgrade your car make this racing game exciting and engaging. Challenge your opponents, customize your car to suit your racing style, and claim victory on the world's most dangerous tracks. This racing game is the perfect entertainment for all lovers of speed and excitement!

Rafaello Appetizer

Ingredients (serves 4)

Cheese - 200 g
Eggs - 4
Garlic - 3-4 cloves (20 g)
Crab sticks - 1 package (200 g)
Mayonnaise - 3 tbsp (100 g)
Lettuce leaves (for serving)

1. Hard-boil the eggs and grate them finely.

2. Add the finely grated cheese.

3. Add the garlic pressed through a press and the mayonnaise. Mix well.

4. Roll the mixture into balls the size of a Rafaello candy and roll them in the finely grated crab sticks.

Serve the Rafaelka appetizer on lettuce leaves.

column8: very good game, bad reviews = skill issue
column9: very good game, bad reviews = skill issue

First, I'll start with the positives: the game has a Russian language, even though Steam indicates it's not. There's enough content for a lengthy playthrough.
Now, to the negatives: what a piece of trash they've turned a derby game series into. Not only are the graphics an order of magnitude worse than even the first game, but the lack of a soundtrack has made the game even worse. The controls have become clumsy and terribly awkward. I don't understand why they added an unnecessary zombie mode (well, at least it's something new), but the implementation is so clumsy. The arena mode is now more like a mush than a mess. In other words, the game has taken a wrong turn and has strayed far from the Flatout I'm used to. I'm so glad I never played this garbage before. But despite all the nuances, I would have given the game a neutral rating, but alas, that's not the case here. Buying it separately is pointless, and as part of a full pack, as I got it, I think it's purely a game for the collection.

The game fully lives up to its "Psychological Horror" label.
Thanks also to the developers for the free epileptic seizure included with the game.

When I first launched the game, I thought it wasn't that bad, but when I started the race, terrible things started happening to me. My face turned pale, my stomach started making brewery noises, and then I shit myself from Flatout 3.

column9:
Standalone title: 2/10
Flatout game: -7/10

I highly recommend against buying this game. Even though it's supposedly a sequel to the iconic second game, you won't experience the same explosive emotions from that game. Throughout my time playing this Frankenstein, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was playing some kind of fusion of a really bad "Hot Wheels" and a pirated version of the first NFS. It's perfectly logical that the game is automatically compared to the second game, and absolutely everything in it is either worse or done poorly. I can't even point out any positives... All the races and challenges are crude and very easy; you might experience some difficulty on the Detroit map and in night racing mode, but otherwise, it's just too bad.

column8:
This feels like a tech demo that should have not been released.
Yes, it's really that bad. (I was surprised it even started up tbh)
-Grass has the same traction as tarmac.
-The AI gets stuck on the walls in demolition derby.
-The AI will bum rush you in demolition derby.
-Boost has a dumb FOV effect.
-The character names feel like temporary ones for when a game is in development. (Xmas-2011, I'm not joking)
-It whinges about not finding the Windows Hardware Experience Index on every startup.
-The grammer just feels off.
-The game needing 10GBs of disk space for this "experience"
-The physics are just silly.
-The AI is far more A than I.
-The AI can take corners as if they're on rails.
-The Splatout gamemode is a lazy ripoff of Carmageddon.
The conclusion: Don't buy it for a serious experience. Only buy it for the memes, achievements and posting witty reviews on Steam.

column8:
16.2% of players have achievement "win one race". Let that sink in.

Opening it reminds me of pre-smartphones phone games, especially racing ones, with simplistic graphics and gameplay. This, I believe, is a fair comparison. Although, on the second thought, comparison would go like "this phone game took less than 150MB space and 1mb ram to achieve much more than Flatout 3 managed to achieve with 10GB of space and whatever ram you got." That is, it would still be a pissing on F3 contest.

When I bought the Flatout game pack and checked each individual game price, I jokingly thought that they included Flatout 3 to make the pack cheaper, that is, it has negative value. And it should be that way; they should pay us to play this piece of dung.

column8:
Holy mf shit... i bought the Flatout Anthology pack on sale for around 10‚Ç¨, and i read the reviews of FO3 and honestly didn't expect it to be as bad as literally everyone has said, well... i was SO damn wrong.

I understand why there's a ''psychological horror'' tag now, because you'll witness the absolute horror that this game is.
Terrible graphics, terrible UI/menus, terrible music and obviously terrible gameplay like TERRIBLE.

This is as far away from Flatout as possible, even though it sadly IS a Flatout game somehow.
Like, i usually don't uninstall games but this was SO terrible that i just HAD to uninstall it, like seriously. It's baaaaaad.

column8:
Straight up not having a good time

Only  Played it so i can write a review

The only thing that works is the quit button and you can put stupid music on your pc and the game will play it 

10/10 
Gift this to people you dont like

Also muffin recipe  for the people who read this

Ingredients
2 medium eggs
125ml vegetable oil
250ml semi-skimmed milk
250g golden caster sugar
400g self-raising flour (or same quantity plain flour and 3 tsp baking powder)
1 tsp salt
100g chocolate chips or dried fruit such as sultanas or dried cherries (optional)
Method
STEP 1
Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Line 2 muffin trays with paper muffin cases. In a large bowl beat 2 medium eggs lightly with a handheld electric mixer for 1 min.

STEP 2
Add 125ml vegetable oil and 250ml semi-skimmed milk and beat until just combined then add 250g golden caster sugar and whisk until you have a smooth batter.

STEP 3
Sift in 400g self-raising flour and 1 tsp salt (or 400g plain flour and 3 tsp baking powder if using) then mix until just smooth. Be careful not to over-mix the batter as this will make the muffins tough.

STEP 4
Stir in 100g chocolate chips or dried fruit if using.

STEP 5
Fill muffin cases two-thirds full and bake for 20-25 mins, until risen, firm to the touch and a skewer inserted in the middle comes out clean. If the trays will not fit on 1 shelf, swap the shelves around after 15 mins of cooking.

STEP 6
Leave the muffins in the tin to cool for a few mins and transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

column9:
[h2]Weak, average[/h2]
The game isn't the worst product, but that doesn't change the fact that it's [b]bad[/b].
The game doesn't even come close to being as good as its two predecessors in terms of quality. It's more like a browser game, and if that were the reality of this game's existence, it wouldn't be bad.
The problem is that [b]Flatout 3[/b] isn't that kind of game ‚Äì what's more, it advertises itself as a sequel to the huge franchise that is [b]Flatout[/b].

Furthermore, it's not a free-to-play game ‚Äì it's monetized and costs 44.99 Polish zloty.

For a game that resembles half a next-door game, we pay [u][b]the same[/b][/u] as the phenomenal sandbox that is [b]Garry's Mod[/b]. I only recommend buying the game if you plan to laugh about it with friends on Discord, try to play it without crashing at 6-7 times per hour, and then return it before you reach the magical 2 hours of playtime.
In any other case, the game isn't worth a penny, and buying it with the expectation of actually having good gameplay is simply foolish.
Thank goodness I didn't waste my money on this product, but my mentally challenged friend did, who gave it to me instead of a Christmas tree switch.
Personally [h1]I don't recommend it[/h1]

As someone who grew up almost exclusively on Team6's cheap shovelware games because of cheapskate parents:

What the hell is this?

[h1]Crooked, Slanted, and Hunchbacked[/h1]
My comparison is based on the first two games in this series. It feels like the previous games were much better optimized and balanced. The controls in the previous games were also more convenient and smooth. No matter what aspect of the game you tackle, this one feels inferior to the previous ones, which is very strange, because time has passed, but instead of improvements, we've received debuffs.

To avoid repetition, let's talk about the voice acting in this game; it feels worse than in the previous ones. Simply completing all the challenges and racing levels will be a challenge due to the game's poor performance. I still couldn't enjoy the game in those 40 hours, and I think this is a sign of poor work on the part of the developers.

The game lacks collectible cards, but it does have achievements, but completing them is excruciatingly tedious due to the clunky controls, so there are no redeeming features here either.

[b][u]To buy or not to buy?[/u][/b]
I bought the bundle with all the games, so I own this game, but otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Don't waste your money.

Flatout 3: Chaos & Destruction is not Flatout.

Pros:

Gameplay - playing on Easy is generally enjoyable. But when you start turning the difficulty up, it becomes painful.

Cars - I liked the models and textures.

Physics - I thought it would be worse, but since I got used to it quickly, I liked it. Except on wet tracks. The physics there are terrible.

Tracks - incredible, but the tracks are easy and overall, you get used to them quickly. I liked the tracks; they're beautiful.

Controls - however, I thought they would be worse. Some cars corner perfectly. Some don't.

Shortcuts - this is the first part of Flatout, where they work perfectly. THANKS TO THE DEVELOPERS!

Controversial points:

Graphics - on the one hand, I liked it. BUT! The glare and shadow issues ruin everything.

Modes - There are some modes like Zombie Crush (Earn To Die in 3D), and racing. But derby and night races are terrible, and the night races are just plain crap. The enemy spawns far away from you, uses nitrous, and flies away, and you have to chase them down (Hello, Flatout).

Optimization - On Windows 10 LTSC 21H2 x64, it launched on the second try, and there were no crashes after that. FPS did drop, of course, only in derby skirmishes.

Cons:

Career - or rather, the lack thereof. If Flatout and Flatout 2 had a career, there was motivation to play. But what about this? Well, I set it to easy and did one lap. I finished it quickly. But there aren't enough tracks... In the end, I finished the game in 3.4 hours.

The technical part - well, I simply couldn't fine-tune the graphics settings, because pressing the down arrow wouldn't click "Yes." And now the best part. The Windows PERFORMANCE INDEX in 2011... The game relies on this index, which, excuse me, is stillborn. Some shadows in the area disappeared. Loading sequences were right in front of your face. A problem with the first and second games.

The AI ‚Äã‚Äãis still just as questionable and stupid. (All the same problems with the first and second games).

Bottom line: you can play on easy difficulty and set the destruction factor to the lowest (which is what I did) with pleasure. It's good for an evening. Otherwise, there are a lot of problems. But I enjoyed it. This isn't Flatout. It's a different game. It doesn't feel like Flatout. The developers have fixed some issues from previous games, but not all of them.

column8: Just create a good racing playlist for yourself, accept that this game is the fifth worst-rated on Steam and try it out: launch if you have it on library or buy it in a bundle with other games with a discount. You may like it if you're looking for something both relaxing and challenging. There is no way to rate this game well by objective measures: it's not a good racing game, but it's weirdness generates some funny and epic moments. It's up to you if you'd like it, just like with any other game - but it certainly doesn't deserve this amount of hate it still has.

The idea is great. The execution sucks. Bugbear should have taken over the production of Part 3, because Part 2 is, in my opinion, the best.
It would be nice to combine them, take the best from both, including the idea from Part 3, new types of tracks, races, and challenges.

But in the end, we have what we have. Tons of bugs, even crashes occasionally on Windows 11. Not to mention the game's creators' extensive testing of their own races. In some places, winning seems impossible. The "Cheat Engine" and advice from the community on the school bus track help. In some places, the opponents are as dumb as a log‚Äîat speed, they can't negotiate any corner, and even a slow tank will take you three laps faster.

Challenge mode‚Äîa sort of completion mode‚Äîhas a greatly inflated damage rate for your car when it touches anything large (opponents, stationary cars, and cars that aren't touching anyone). Often, you simply won't be able to make it through all 3/3 of the circles alive. Oh well, you can survive that, who knows how many tries it takes, but you can.

The physics are terrible. It doesn't compare to the 2nd or 4th flatout.
Basically, it's a minus here, a minus on top of a minus. The game was rushed together.

column8:
It worked for me and didn't really have any bugs at all, so not sure what the Overwhelmingly Negative review is about...

However, AI seems pretty trashy and the graphics are pretty rough. There are some things that just don't seem to make sense, and the Nightshift and Splatter levels leave a lot to be desired visually.

Cars get better as you go on, but the races get harder as well so it's just not super fun to play. Achievements are probably doable but I really don't know. ~30-40% to get a taste of winning in each mode.

column8:
This is truly, something else to behold oneself to, or....expose oneself too.

Right off the bat, before I even loaded up the game, I ran into a bug. Apparently, there's an error when starting up this game that affects some users, all depending on their system, or more likely, chance. I attempted to install this on my original PC I played most of my steam games on for the last several years. And it simply wouldn't work.
 I tried many work arounds but nothing worked. 
Lo and behold, I forgot I installed this on my new PC. And it did work, no problems at all. Except well, when I began playing.

It's almost overwhelming when you compare what this game achieves and well, is objectively compared to the two prior titles in the franchise. Overwhelming in the face of what this series began as, and how the new development team went about in the third full entry into the series. It feels like it's supposed to be a mockery of the games that came out just about 5 years prior to this one. 
I struggle to see how this is even related to Flatout, other than feeling like a fan-fiction made by borrowing elements of the prior games without capturing the true game mechanics and atmosphere. It genuinely reminds me of a mobile game, like Candy Crush. Or Angry Birds. Except this game makes one feel more like an Angry Bird when playing this game which should've had top honours in the equivalent of the Golden Raspberry Awards for videogames of 2011.
I can't find a single thing to praise this game for, for in every regard, it feels like a step, naw, a sprint backwards. 
I've had more fun playing flash games. I tried every gamemode to give myself the full experience, and cannot for the life of me understand the thinking that went into development and release of this.

Considering the developers went into mobile game development, why am I not surprised that this feels like an IP for the mobile gaming market. Heck, they already inserted the ragdoll mechanics into a mobile format.

Just don't bother touching this. It's not just bad, it's soul destroying.

column8:
MEME REVIEW: Have to downvote to continue this game's legacy as one of the worst rated games on Steam, however.......

I did have fun. The AI is terrible and the rubber-banding is strong, sometimes the enemies will drift at top speed around corners and the graphics OMG.... the bloom is so obnoxious and the game is so orange you might go blind. The physics is so bad, especially when jumping ramps and the collision detection.... and you might clip something you can barely tell is an obstacle that will end your race. 

On the upside, you can set career mode events to one lap, meaning you can charge through most races in under a minute and not lose a lot when you restart maybe. Flatout 3 did make an effort to carry on the legacy of the previous entries with the additional content and bonus modes and there are some fun to be had there but you wish there was more and that some of the events were better executed.

The soundtrack which has been a hall mark of the identity of the series returns with equal aplomb, with lesser known artist than the previous installment, but although a mixed bag of wailing rock and energetic numbers, I believe has been well-received by those that hold the game near and dear to their heart...

Doing reviews for an old forgotten game like this might be a bit redundant now as racing games and technologies have progressed, but to take a moment to appreciate the nostalgia and to see where we've come from. Honestly a big part of the negative reception to this game was the high expectations set by its predecessors and part of me wants to appreciate the spirit with which the series was attempted to be carried on here.

As with some genres, we've seen a decline in range in car combat games, like arena shooters maybe as well, I mean there's like three good ones and infinite bad ones where there is that perception that people will never get tired of tried-and-tested classics and the consensus usually ends up being why don't we see more of these games, but secretly we know these genres and recent attempts have been stale and subpar and boring and met with indifference in the greater market.

In that I think this game does deserve recognition in what it tries to be, and despite its numerous technical flaws, I find myself asking if I would play this if its the only game I have and the answer is yes.

(Also seen a price increase recently and is now three times more expensive than I payed. There is an issue brooding over pricing in games. Its not what it costs but what you can make people pay.... In that there is a caveat of 'Its good depending what you pay' which is unprovisioned in reviews systems unless explicitly mentioned.)

column9:
I don't usually leave reviews on video games, but I think it's worth letting you know that this is the worst piece of garbage I've ever "played." But it's so garbage that I didn't even want to keep playing it. I only played for 20 minutes and realized it's not worth wasting my time on this thing.

If Flatout 1 and 2 had anything good, it was their gameplay, graphics, well-designed maps, and good music. Well, this game has none of those.

Gameplay: AWFUL
Graphics: HORRIBLE. THEY LOOK LIKE GRAPHICS FROM A GAME FROM BEFORE 2000.
MUSIC: NONE. YOU JUST HEAR THE UGLY SOUND OF UGLY CARS.
MAP DESIGN: TRULY, THEY'RE TOO HORRIBLE. THOSE MAPS MAKE NO SENSE.

CONCLUSION: DO NOT BUY THE GAME, MUCH LESS IF IT IS ON SALE. IT IS NOT WORTH SPENDING A FEW CENTS ON THIS GARBAGE.

column8:
Replace the 'FL' in the game title with 'SH' and you get a perfectly succinct descriptor of what this game feels like.

Buy it if you want to gain a deeper appreciation of how other racing games and developers do a comparatively godly job with AI, car handling, track design (with decent signposting), graphics and audio. 

Seriously, you will come to admire how well other racing games lead your eye around the track to give you an idea where you're going. This game has an infamous reputation and it's fully deserving of the criticisms thrown at it. Yet perversely, I have had some entertainment out of it as a cheap knockabout racer, albeit one that appears to have been thrown together with little testing.

Made by Team 6 (not Bugbear like the previously well regarded entries in the series), this feels like a shovelware PS2/Wii game. I can only assume that the 6 in the developer's name refers to either the amount of devs they put on the game or the maximum time in months they took to develop it; probably both. It comes across like a quickly churned out knockoff that fails to grasp (or replicate) what made the originals so enjoyable - merely existing to cynically leverage the brand name at the time. 

Received as part of the complete pack, I thought I'd give it a go after Ultimate Carnage (the game I really wanted to play) refused to start up. I wasn't expecting much (which it delivers on) but it is possible to get some fun out of it for a while despite all that is shonky, broken and just bad. There is certainly some chaos and destruction to be had, some of the cars handle okay-ish and changing the speed in races to 'classic' instead of default makes things a little more manageable. There's enough modes to keep you occupied a while but none feel like they've had enough attention or refinement.

I wouldn't even recommend it to achievement hunters as some of them are tied to seemingly impossible tasks that are more likely to come down to luck - some of the stunt events feel broken due to the unhelpful camera/physics, and the night races with magical rain that sometimes lands in the air several feet above the road surface, appear to be filled with opposition that can supernaturally whizz and boost around the track as if guided by a divine hand.

It's a shame the brand got lumbered with this sequel, just enjoy the first 2 games and/or Flatout: Ultimate Carnage (an updated version of Flatout 2) instead - they're a lot of fun (the 2nd being perhaps one of my favourite racers).

FlatOut 3: Chaos & Destruction is a high-octane racing experience that brings a whole new level of chaos to the track. While it may have divided opinions, there's no denying the adrenaline-fueled excitement that this installment brings to the table.

One of the standout features of FlatOut 3 is its sheer commitment to over-the-top destruction. The crashes are spectacular, and the debris scattered across the track adds a layer of unpredictability, keeping every race intense and unpredictable. The variety of environments, from urban landscapes to off-road tracks, adds a refreshing change of scenery and ensures that no two races feel the same.

The vehicle customization options are a welcome addition, allowing players to tweak and modify their cars to suit their preferred racing style. The expansive roster of vehicles provides a diverse range of choices, each with its own strengths and quirks, adding an extra layer of strategy to the gameplay.

Multiplayer modes contribute significantly to the game's replay value. Competing against friends or online opponents in the chaotic races or destructive derbies is an absolute blast. The multiplayer component enhances the social aspect of the game, turning every race into a shared experience of laughter and competition.

While the game may not adhere to the strictest simulation standards, its focus on delivering pure, unadulterated fun is evident. The soundtrack complements the fast-paced action perfectly, enhancing the overall immersive experience.

In conclusion, FlatOut 3: Chaos & Destruction is a game that revels in its commitment to delivering an action-packed, destructive racing experience. It might not be for everyone, but for those who appreciate a bit of mayhem on the track, it's an exhilarating joyride that's well worth checking out. Strap in, rev up those engines, and get ready for a wild, chaotic adventure!

FlatOut 3 is a mixed bag, to say the least. On one hand, it offers a surprisingly fun and enjoyable gaming experience. The high-speed, chaotic races and the ability to wreck opponents' cars in spectacular fashion are undeniably entertaining. The game's focus on destruction and mayhem provides a unique and adrenaline-pumping twist to the racing genre. It's a blast to unleash your inner road rage and wreak havoc on the track.

However, the glaring downside to FlatOut 3 lies in its graphical department. The visuals are nothing short of mediocre, even when considering the time of its release. The textures are often dull, and the overall presentation lacks the polish and finesse that gamers have come to expect in modern titles. If you're a stickler for high-quality graphics, you might be disappointed by the underwhelming visuals.

But perhaps the most frustrating aspect of the game is its stability. It's no exaggeration to say that I was fortunate to get onto the game twice. Frequent crashes mar the experience, making it difficult to enjoy the game without frustration. This is a significant letdown, as a game with such potential for enjoyment is hampered by these technical issues.

In conclusion, FlatOut 3 is a game with a split personality. It offers an exhilarating and fun racing experience with its unique focus on destruction, but this is marred by underwhelming graphics and a maddeningly unstable performance. If you're willing to overlook these shortcomings and enjoy the chaos of racing mayhem, it might be worth a shot. However, if you're looking for a technically sound and visually stunning racing game, you might want to look elsewhere.

[h1] "One of the best hours of my life" [/h1]

There's no point in being sarcastic about this game, since everyone already knows that the ersatz Flat Out 3 is a raging possum's dung, whose developers decided to dishonestly cash in on the name of its predecessor, which gave people the crazy derby-street racing simulator that many people know, remember, love, and probably still play/replay.
The game was on sale and literally cost me a round-trip bus ride, so I decided to fully experience this "harmful freebie." As a teenager, my verdict was quite quick and harsh after two races, but here I can dive in and figure out for the second and final time what's really wrong with this game. But since the flaws and jokes have already been overlooked a hundred times, I'll still stand out and point out the only positive I did notice in this blurry, freezing work by a senior polytechnic student:

Aside from the whistled demolition derbies, stunts, and classic circuit racing, "Flatout 3" does have some cool modes, like team racing on Bigfoot trucks or duels with poor visibility and pendulum-like objects, that can create competitive interest and easily ruin the lead or the entire race. Of course, if this product had been polished properly.
If this game had been released before 2007, or at most before 2008, and under a different, original name; If the developers had just tweaked the physics a little and removed those blurry freezes I mentioned, the game, even if it hadn't become a leader in gaming magazines and websites, would definitely have received positive reviews and would have definitely found its audience and even a fan base.
PS: I tried running this piece of crap several times because I kept getting an error. I had to download a patch from a thread about this issue, which also didn't help. However, after about the fifth try, the game finally stopped throwing me out like a whale on the beach. Even the creators, apparently, warn users against running this game snuff.
Unfortunately, I couldn't resist making a joke...

column8:
I have an unbelievable take, this game isn't good, but it is EXTREMELY overhated.

When I sat down to play, I had the lowest of the low expectations. Bad physics, bad sound, bad AI, bad game.

Imagine my surprise when I sat and played, and actually had fun. When I play this game, I experience everything as the developers had intended. Finding new shortcuts, pushing limits, finding out what car I liked and refining my driving, and you know what? For what it is, as long as it's $5 or less, you could do a LOT worse than this. The driving feels like the car turns from the back wheel, the physics are unforgiving and unpredictable if you didn't grow up playing Wii racing games (oh boy were they worse, save for Mario Kart,) and I had fun. I actually am looking forward to playing more of this game for what it is; silly janky racing fun with light customization and pure chaos. Would I buy it for $10? No, absolutely not. It should be a flat $5 at most. If it's on sale for 50% or more, which it does basically every time it goes on sale, and you crave silly racing with too much bloom because the game is from 2009, then this is it. Just be realistic with it.

Flatout 3: Chaos & Destruction is a racing game that offers players exciting races and thrilling clashes on destructible tracks. While the game has its advantages, it also has a few drawbacks.

Pros:

1. Environmental Destructibility: Flatout 3 offers impressive environmental destructibility, adding realism to racing clashes. You can knock down obstacles, destroy buildings, and create chaos on the track.

2. Wide Range of Cars: The game offers a wide variety of different cars, each with its own unique characteristics and capabilities. This allows players to choose the best cars for specific tracks and situations.

3. Diverse Game Modes: Flatout 3 offers several game modes, including regular races, as well as capture the flag and destruction modes. This adds variety to the gameplay and allows players to experience different aspects of racing.

Cons:

1. Game Creation

Overall, Flatout 3: Chaos & Destruction offers a fun and chaotic racing experience that may appeal to fans of this genre. If you're interested in racing games with a focus on destruction and collisions, Flatout 3 may be a good choice, but be aware of its shortcomings.
